I was debating with myself if I should ask for a refund since the Python part, and you know what, if you reach Django part, you are not able to ask for a refund.

results.content:
The course is very comprehensive. It's a great way to get started with Django. Out of the course, you would definitely know how to use Django for building your own applications. 

I love the level of detail of the instructor, and also the perfectionism attitude on the course in keeping the code clean and organized.

Some feedback to the instructor:
1. I believe some of the Django lectures could be shorter. There's a lot of information that isn't a priority to learn for someone who is starting with Django. You can achieve the same goals, objectives, and functionalities with less information/steps in the lectures that aren't really required. I believe the Django section could be shortened to three lectures instead of five.
2. Related to that same point, there are some steps that would explain how to do something specific, but then in a following lecture, you would learn that actually, you won't use what you just learned, because there's a simpler way to do it. It's better to go straight to the way you would actually be using. (I understand that probably the reasoning behind this is to understand how it actually works, but it's pretty clear already what built-in modules and classes do.
3. In some lectures, we could probably be more creative on using different names for variables, classes, forms, models, etc. Some lectures use the same variable names as built-in modules, other classes, etc. and you suddenly have the same name for many different things. This could create confusion of what the name is referring to. A good way to avoid this that I have seen in other courses is to do a very very simple "real-world" application. This way, you can name things differently (related to the app) instead of the type (model, form, etc.). 

Other than that, great!

Thanks,
results.content_html:

results.content: One of those complete courses, that actually work well. You can skip ahead certain lectures and practice projects, if you are a little more experienced. The best part is that the course actually covers both front-end and the back-end of web-development. It is not a language specific course, though. So, you will not be a master of HTML, CSS, JS, Python or Django, but you would get enough to bring things together. You can always take language-specific course before or after to deepen your knowledge. Again, this course gives you enough to decently understand and implement the basics of all these concepts/languages.

results.content: I took the course years after it was developed, apparently. It was still a good course, and I hope that I didn't miss out on too much new functionality. I did have to do extra debugging, because my versions of Django (etc.) are much newer. Towards the end of the course, I had a bit of trouble seeing the forest for the trees. I was able to code along and debug my issues, but didn't have as good an overall view of the clone projects as I would like. I was tempted to try to use something like django_trace to understand the execution flow, but eventually just wanted to finish the course and move along to something different.

results.content:
Djangoが過去のバージョンで開発されていて、動画で解説されているコードの多くがそのまま移植出来ない。Django ２.x以降用のコードも付録ファイルとして付属しているが、その解説はない。コースの最初にバージョンの相違は学習の理解の大きな妨げにならないと言っていたが、実際にWebサービスを開発する段階になると５つ以上のフォルダに３０近いファイルがあり、そのどこかに何らかの違いがあり、それらを全て発見してもう一度理解し直す必要が生まれる。完全に二度手間で時間の無駄である。Django2.0での開発を行いたい人は別の講座をオススメします。
英語は聞き取りやすいので過去のバージョンでもいい人はオススメしますが、わざわざ古いバージョンでやりたい人はいないでしょう。

results.content:
What an amazing course! This is my second course by Jose. I find him engaging, knowledgeable and able to anticipate and deal with concepts that students may find difficult to grasp.
The course itself is epic and does a great job of tying together all the elements of full-stack development, with a surprising amount of depth in each subject. By the end of the front-end section, I was throwing together really slick and modern-looking websites.
The django section is a grind, which is exactly the feeling you're supposed to get when tackling a framework like django. Jose digs deep and naturally incorporates practice work into the lectures, so it doesn't feel like you're exam hell.
results.content_html:

results.content:
It is very detailed course where you can learn from absolute zero. There are good sections about html, css, bootstrap, python, javascript and of course Django. I came with very basic understanding about how web development works -- now it’s more ground and I know what should I learn next. I get a big picture of how Django framework works and how all parts are connected. Even now, right after finishing this course I feel strong enough to start simple Django project.

I learn Docker in parallel and launched all course materials in Docker. I recommend Jose Portilla to update course with basic Docker section because it’s an industry standard now.

In conclusion, Python and Django Full Stack Web Developer Bootcamp is brilliant course. Jose Portilla did a very good and difficult work. Thank you a lot! I recommend that course for all how want to start web development.

results.content:
I challenge you to find a better or more comprehensive course that is appropriate for as broad an audience as this one.  Jose is very detailed, but to the point.  He assumes no knowledge and yet, as an experienced coder, I always learn new tricks and approaches to common problems.  You can tell great thought was put into the flow of the content and into modularizing it so that you can easily focus on what you need and skip what you don't.

This course covers everything you need to get started with full stack development in Django.  I would highly recommend it to anyone who is interested in building their own web-based applications.
results.content_html:
I challenge you to find a better or more comprehensive course that is appropriate for as broad an audience as this one. Jose is very detailed, but to the point. He assumes no knowledge and yet, as an experienced coder, I always learn new tricks and approaches to common problems. You can tell great thought was put into the flow of the content and into modularizing it so that you can easily focus on what you need and skip what you don't.

This course covers everything you need to get started with full stack development in Django. I would highly recommend it to anyone who is interested in building their own web-based applications.

results.content:
The course is a decent introduction to full stack web development and a good introduction to Django. It starts out pretty easy with the front-end stuff, HTML, CSS and a little bit of JS. Then it picks up the pace with Django which covers more than half of the course.

The course could do with a bit more theory, or some technology overviews. Most of the course is a big 'code-along' session, which is okay but a little more theory would be great. More on this in "Cons" below.

All of the 32 hours of material can be covered in less than 10 days if you really power through.

Pros:
- A decent introductory course for web development.
- A good overview of Django.
- Great instructor, easy to understand

Cons:
- Code-along can get a bit tiresome. It would have been helpful to get a higher lever overview of some topics, and maybe get a technology comparison. At times (especially near the end) it felt like I was copying what the instructor was typing, which in turn felt like he was copying from his notes.
- Does not cover any system design. (scaling, distributed, load balancing, caching, etc.) This would definitely be out of scope but it would have been nice to get an overview at the end.
- No devops, which may be out of scope, but again, a brief overview would be nice.
- Very little on dynamic websites (AJAX, etc.)

results.content:
This was the first course I've ever bought and I was tricked by high rates. Unfortunately I haven't looked all the reviews.
The course is super outdated - Django Version 1.10! Every lesson you need to google something or go to stackoverflow to find some answers. The course is also ugly because of teaching style. "That makes sense" - this is the most favourite phrase of Jose, he uses it in every situation when he doesn't want to explain something. 
The full understanding of Python and Django came to me only after going through another courses, not this.
And the most weird thing that if you want to return your money you need to do this in a period of 30 days and you have to cover less than 50% of the course. But "Django Topics" start as a second half of a course, so when you start realize that Django is outdated and you need to spend lots of time searching for additional info you won't have an ability to return your money.
So be careful and don't buy this course.

results.content:
The way Jose explains the logic between Templates - Urls - Views - Models is very messy for me, or at least it was at the beginning.

When i was following the course i would find myself doing stuff without really knowing what it meant, i couldn't see the bigger picture because Jose was not putting into a beginner perspective. Of course when you're more experienced in webdev, the thinking path might make sense..

Anyway, the course is super outdated and if you're doing it on Django 3 you'll have to browse a lot of stuff in order to debug (of course you'll learn a lot by browsing, but if i wanted to learn everything from the Django documentation i wouldn't buy the course).

One thing i forgot to mention is how Jose just simply ignores certain stuff because it seems... too complicated? idk, but when we're overriding default class methods, i couldn't really figure out what was really happening.. It was more of a lecture of "do it like this because i say so".

results.content:
UPDATE: raised rating from 2.5 to 3.5 stars, based on the quality of the Django-specific material.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
Three reasons:
1) Based on the course title, I expected to be learning Python right off the bat, and then Django. Unfortunately, a large amount of the content (~ 1/3-rd of the lessons?) is not on those two technologies ('as advertised'), instead that content covers other technologies, like: HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Bootstrap, and jQuery.

2) The instructor is all too often sloppy in their use of terminology. Sometimes this is relatively minor/innocuous ("outputted" -- not really a word) for 'emitted' or 'returned'. 
But other times they're actually using a completely wrong word (i.e., a word with a significantly different meaning). For example, the instructor repeatedly uses the word "cast" (or "casted" (sic)). That word has a specific meaning in Computer Science/Programming languages: it means an EXPLICIT reinterpretation (without data conversion) of the existing, underlying bits of the data. Unlike C/C++, Python does NOT support a cast operation. Instead it supports _data conversion_. For example: num = int('3')
Sorry, but that level of sloppiness makes me doubt the instructor's authoritativeness and depth of understanding.

3) Slightly broken or incorrect code examples by instructor. For example, (if I'm remembering the correct location): in the video for Python_Level_One / Part9 Solutions / Problem 5, the instructor forgets to include the 'in' boolean operator in their solution, rendering the result completely non-functional.

Based on issue 2), I'm concerned that I may be getting some mis-conceptions in my learning; based on issue 3), I'm concerned that I'm going to have to double-check every bug (or misunderstanding) that I run into against an independent source of information on Python or Django, in order to know whether what I'm doing is wrong, or the instructor's code is wrong or sloppy . . .

On the plus side, the pacing seems pretty good (for an already experienced programmer); I can't comment on what it might be like for a novice.

Sorry, wish I could give a more positive review.

results.content:
This is a great introduction course to Django framework. The explanation of every topic is very clear and easy to understand. The instructor's voice is pleasant to listen to which I find very important in an online class. 
The only thing I somewhat disliked was the final code-along project, where many advanced topics that were used during the project were introduced without any real explanation. Stuff like advanced class methods, overwriting built in generic class methods, etc. Also the version of Django used in the course is quite dated, but this was not a big problem for me. 
I really hope Jose Portilla will make an advanced Django course using the latest technologies, I would immediately sign up for that!
results.content_html:

results.content: I learned and enjoyed a lot in this class. The lectures are organized well. The instructor is very clear. This is a perfect class for beginners. It covers both the front end and back end. Be sure to check the Q&A forum. I found many of my questions answered already. For those who already know the basics of web development, this class may not be so helpful. I still have tons of questions and I can see myself searching and reading a lot later on, but because I took this class, I know where to find solutions and help. I highly recommend this class to beginners who want to learn web dev with Django.

results.content:
This is a good course that besides Django, walks you through basics of HTML, CSS, jQuery, JavaScript, Bootstrap. I was new to these ones and those lessons were valuable for me. I would really like to see the Django part improved. 
- the version of Django and Python are not uptodate, so you constantly need to debug for the differences
- the projects examples do not convey to build something usefull (eg. there are small projects to test templates/forms/users but they are not put together to build something more usefull, eg. a blog, a site, etc.)
- lack of "homeworks" in the Django chapters. The other chapters of the course contain challenges that you can work on by yourself. In the Django part - the most difficult one in the course, lacks these challenges and the approach is more of "code along with me, feel free to copy+paste the notes". Some concepts are not explained very well. 
- You are given a lot of explanations in the first chapters, which are the easy ones, but the number decreases as the difficulty of the concepts increases.
I recommend this course if you are a not beginner on these topics together with the youtube tutorials of Corey Schafer and Dennis Ivy.
Happy Coding, everybody! :)

This course is absolutely fantastic. I'm already a developer, but my main focus is Java, so many of the concepts were not new to me, but the way the basics were covered was excellent. In the HTML, CSS, Bootstrap section I actually picked up quite a few new things that I didn't know (Started using HTML back in the mid/late 90s). 

The JavaScript/J Query section was pretty awesome as well. Learned a lot there as I had never used JavaScript at all, but definitely will after this.

Python coverage was great from a programming and language standpoint and I'm heading into the Django section now and I'm not expecting it to be any less than what I've encountered already.

results.content:
Excellent course. Great in-depth explanation of content, and exercises given helped me understand content better. 

I really enjoyed this course because I was able to follow along, pause the video if I was stuck, and was able to find any errors quite easily in my code if there was something wrong.

I enjoyed the two projects in the course, (Blog Clone Project and Social Media Site Clone Project), however I would have enjoyed a third project that had more real world applications to it, perhaps a Shopping Site Clone project, like Amazon, where we can include certain functions like payment options (PayPal, Stripe, venmo etc.). This is just my own personal preference. 

This course has a ton of material, and it was extremely helpful in learning another language (I'm already familiar with Javascript). 

This course allowed me to understand and use Python and Django and I really did enjoy it.

results.content:
This is a great course for getting a grasp on full stack web development. Jose is really competent and is nicely calm to listen to. 
When finishing this course you are able to setup simple django websites and have a solid base to advance. Although the websites you make are simple they cover a lot of necessary knowledge of modern day web/software development. Mind you, however simple don't expect easy! Great course. Thorough explanation and reasonable pace, and good examples. Only two downsides:
1- Uses Django 1.x when the most recent version is 3.0X
2- First half of the course is really basic HTML, CSS, and Javascript. However, this is not a big negative as you can simply skip those sections

Even though the core concepts haven't changed, but I just wish the author would update the videos to the latest Django version.

results.content:
Good enough course for the basic understanding of the stack and how web apps work. Resources and projects are really good. Jose really knows how to teach, even if you are a complete fresher you will get great value out of this.
 The only con is that the course is old, uses bootstrap 3.37 current is 4.4.1 and Django version 1 current version is 3.8 as of April 2020. Due to this difference, it extended my course completion time by ~10% but, fortunately, I have experience with programming so your experience may vary.

**Also the description says Rest APIs, it's not there.
results.content_html:
Good enough course for the basic understanding of the stack and how web apps work. Resources and projects are really good. Jose really knows how to teach, even if you are a complete fresher you will get great value out of this.
The only con is that the course is old, uses bootstrap 3.37 current is 4.4.1 and Django version 1 current version is 3.8 as of April 2020. Due to this difference, it extended my course completion time by ~10% but, fortunately, I have experience with programming so your experience may vary.

**Also the description says Rest APIs, it's not there.

results.content:
Курс действительно полный и объёмный. Жалею, что не нашел его в начале обучения. Единственный минус - это проекты (два клона сайтов). Для начинающего будет сложно уследить за логикой и всё успеть. Даже в реальной разработке код целиком не пишется. Приходится постоянно запускать сервер и проверять работоспособность каждого этапа.
Автор избрал другой подход. Сначала полностью пишется код проекта, а затем запускается и происходит отладка.
А в целом - курс отличный! Рекомендую.

results.content: Class gives a great overview of how to create websites with Django. I started with a moderate amount of experience with HTML/CSS/JS and Python, but all of these subjects are covered so that you can start as a beginner, the projects are fun and allow you to test out real world applications of the technology. The instructor presents the material in a clear and understandable way and questions are answered promptly.
results.content_html: Class gives a great overview of how to create websites with Django. I started with a moderate amount of experience with HTML/CSS/JS and Python, but all of these subjects are covered so that you can start as a beginner, the projects are fun and allow you to test out real world applications of the technology. The instructor presents the material in a clear and understandable way and questions are answered promptly.

results.content: I am a newbie in web development and I wished that I could find a course which provides basic knowledge with guides step by step to develop a website. Finally, my wish came true - maybe Santa heard me :D. Although this is a Python and Django course, I like how you added the introduce about font-end such as HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Bootstrap and the explanation about what happens when you open up your browser and visit a website. They are useful. The course gave me information in a systematic way so I can learn fast and remember the necessary points as well. Thank you very much for creating this wonderful course!

results.content:
I have just finished the bulk of the first section on Django itself. This is all good material and I'm happy to be making some progress on this but there are times where the 'why' for what is instructed is not thoroughly explained enough. This is especially important for some of the more basic concepts like mapping templates and URLs within the Django projects. I find myself having to refer to the lecture over and over again and having to keep at least one Google tab open at all times due to the number of topics not being covered quite well enough. 

Also, on a more subjective note, the teacher's apparent hatred of spaces makes his code rather hard to read to me sometimes. #nitpicky

I can definitely learn from this series but it's gonna take a bit more review from this and other sources before I'm totally comfortable with some of the concepts shown here. 

My hope is that, as I progress, the pieces will begin to fall into place a little better. I will update my review once I finish this course.

results.content:
There is a lot about css, html, jquery, and javascript before getting to django and python - so either skip ahead or be prepared for something that you  may already know if you are not new to web development. The instructor does a good job of covering those topics quickly and well, pointing to areas for more learning or documentation if needed. There are also many other courses that cover some of these topics more in depth. 

As the course moves into Python it offers a good general overview of python to understand what you are doing before you do it in the django framework. I've seen other courses jump right in to building things in the framework and I'm not sure what is best. I would have appreciated more django specific things up front but I don't think the layout of the course is bad. It's really good if you are brand new to web development and looking to learn the basics and then django, along with having a good deal of patience.

The projects at the end of each section are well thought out for the most part and the solutions are helpful. If would suggest doing them on your own, I don't think the instructor emphasizes that enough.
results.content_html:
There is a lot about css, html, jquery, and javascript before getting to django and python - so either skip ahead or be prepared for something that you may already know if you are not new to web development. The instructor does a good job of covering those topics quickly and well, pointing to areas for more learning or documentation if needed. There are also many other courses that cover some of these topics more in depth.

As the course moves into Python it offers a good general overview of python to understand what you are doing before you do it in the django framework. I've seen other courses jump right in to building things in the framework and I'm not sure what is best. I would have appreciated more django specific things up front but I don't think the layout of the course is bad. It's really good if you are brand new to web development and looking to learn the basics and then django, along with having a good deal of patience.

The projects at the end of each section are well thought out for the most part and the solutions are helpful. If would suggest doing them on your own, I don't think the instructor emphasizes that enough.

results.content:
This should be split up. 
All the simple HTML CSS JavaScript at the start. That is Novice. 
Those sections should be a prerequisite for this class.

At the projects section near the end. We had real opportunity to get deep into every aspect of Django. Like how to change the name of the filters in the admin. (add verbose_name in the model attribute your filtering by). How to have two forms on the same page? There was a real opportunity to show us this when we made the Sign Up and Login page with the Auth.models. Then with bootstrap use a Tab section to jump between the forms.

It also would of been nice to have pseudo code files to download. With all the variables and class names that you'll be using. Then as I watch the code along. I can see how you write it vs how I wrote it. 

We skimmed the surfaces and this is a good introductory course to Django. If anything, I would change this from All levels to Beginner Python - Django

I would love to have a Intermediate and Advanced section. Going over all the "Batteries" that are "included" with Django.

At the projects section near the end. We had real opportunity to get deep into every aspect of Django. Like how to change the name of the filters in the admin. (add verbose_name in the model attribute your filtering by). How to have two forms on the same page? There was a real opportunity to show us this when we made the Sign Up and Login page with the Auth.models. Then with bootstrap use a Tab section to jump between the forms.

It also would of been nice to have pseudo code files to download. With all the variables and class names that you'll be using. Then as I watch the code along. I can see how you write it vs how I wrote it.

We skimmed the surfaces and this is a good introductory course to Django. If anything, I would change this from All levels to Beginner Python - Django

I would love to have a Intermediate and Advanced section. Going over all the "Batteries" that are "included" with Django.

results.content:
Jose is hands on one of the topnotch instructors on Udemy. For a long time, I struggled with finding the right kind of instructors for my style of learning. I bought and ended up struggling with other instructors who taught the same kind of skillset. 

Here is why I have found success with Jose's style of coaching
1. He will starts small and builds on things slowly and methodically
2. He explains the concepts in a very detailed way, but does not overdo it. This makes it easy to understand something new and also easier to be engaged because it makes you think.
3. He has the right supporting material for you to read after the videos
4. Delivery style is uniform. 
5. He does not introduce terms randomly. I found this especially useful because I was able to focus on the concept I was learning rather than being distracted trying to understand something else unrelated.

Jose : Keep up the good work. You are changing lives for the better. We, your students at Udemy appreciate all the hard work you are putting into this.

results.content:
To be honest, the whole course was awesome, indeed. I did learn so much from it, and it covered the knowledge that a Full Stack Web Developer needs to acquire.
In general, the basic knowledge of each session are, on some degree, well explained, but in the back session, like, in the clone part, there are some many things have not been talked about, and what I could do was following the video to code, and google them (THIS IS What a Learner does).
Besides, Some of the version of the libraries(?) are only compatible with older version django , so, get used to google them.
However, even though I finished all the lectures, but I am still not confident enough to say I could get a job by using django, Could I have any suggestions before I use it to face the real-world?

results.content: Great Course, I'm a huge fan of Jose and think his style of teaching is exceptional, it's been great to take part in another one of his courses. This course really gives you everything you need to start your journey. It doesn't teach you everything but more importantly teaches you how to find what you need and further your knowledge on your own. He has clearly gone through each subject ensuring a good understanding of the foundational theories. Then we build on it, and whenever I didn't understand, I carried on through the section and by the end, always understand exactly what the code was doing. My only criticism could be the lack of teaching on say, downloadable templates and more real-life like clone projects like a business landing page or e-commerce website and maybe even credit-card entry and housing. However, rest assured, this is a small criticism in a space of huge compliments. Easily recommend!

Should be followed using Django 1.10. Using Django 2 will cause confusion in some of the code as there is some changes that need to be made. The instructor does an amazing job at the lectures, The only drawback is that we are mostly newbies at all this and trying to learn. When someone asks a question, we are often referred to looking it up ourselves in the documents, which most of us do not understand, since we are all new at this. There are plenty of other users that will help with questions.

results.content:
Money well spent!. I learned a lot in this course, from my point of view it's quite complete. If you are a beginner or first timer, this is a quite interesting course. One point I loved of it it's that you get projects to work in after every lesson (it's fairly easy to watch a video, then you imagine you understood it, but not until do you try it, you are sure you really know.
I don't really have any bad review for the course, I more experience programmer might have some issues, who knows but for me everything seems ok and reasonable. Maybe the last projects it's a bit quick, he introduces quite a lot of new concepts  that aren't mentioned in any previous videos, i got the idea that, even though I got the same project, everyone else could've done the same just by following the lectures, I for sure, re-watch it again.

I wouldn't really change anything in this course, having said that, I'd do the exact same course but level 2, a bit more of html, css, java, python django...

To summarize, if you have no programming experience, or just the grasp of it, do the course, I doubt you regret.

results.content:
This is the second course by Jose Portilla that I took recently.  Quite extensive one, but well organized and commented along the way.
It was a lot to take in, but I found the videos well presented and the content clearly explained most of the time.

There are also many valuable references to various external sources and third-party tools/libraries.  Read everything you can and go through the FAQ section ... you will not regret it!

Personally, I had to do a lot of extra reading along the way to fully understand some of the concepts.  I found that some lectures were based on older versions, so I had to change some coding on the fly.  Nothing major though.

Also, a bit of syncing problem between the content of the online course and the zip file provided.

I only wished that Jose would have considered including an extra chapter about project planning and dev workflows.  Maybe some insides on how people organize and deploy projects in real life, best IDEs that exist today, etc.  Maybe a graphical representation of the actual deployment workflow, or maybe a video presentation on the matter, would have been also of great value for some of us (models, views, urls, templates, what goes where and when).

We only briefly touched the deployment pipeline via github using pythonanywhere, but we never got the chance to see it in action full circle, to better understand how a developer would pack and push a new project to the host. 

Overall, a good learning experience that I personally enjoyed going through.  A good value for the money I would say.

Once again, many thanks to Jose for his work on this program.

results.content:
The course is great overall. However, I think two site clone project sections could be done better by the author. You write code for three hours and see the results at the end. This style does not really help understand the implications of the code written. In my opinion, it would be better if you could see how making some small incremental change affects the site you are building. Writing all the code at once really makes it difficult to connect the dots. 
I really think that site clone projects should be done at a much detailed level and be central idea in this course.

results.content:
(My background: iOS developer (5y+), very unexperienced in web development, built a few Flash websites 10y ago)


I really liked the first part of this course, the general introduction to web development, useful tools, and the introduction to JavaScript. It was straightforward, easy and fun for me to follow along!

But I did not like the introduction to Python (parts one and two) very much:
- the explanations, examples, and exercises are not chosen and structured very well. Sometimes language features are used out of the blue without much of an explanation. Everything feels a bit like random.  Sometimes very basic things are repeated again and again (like the difference between a string and an integer), while more complicated stuff like "why and how to use a lambda expression?" does not get as much attention. 
- It's also not at all a good introduction to OOP in general or good programming practices. It only touches these topics in an unstructured, and a bit amateurish way. 
- the 'code challenges' (homeworks) are few, and not well chosen. E.g. the 'simple game' exercise does not focus on practicing the things covered in the previous lessons, but on the tricky game logic.
- the instructor probably writes much more JavaScript code than Python, since he intuitively always writes camelCase instead of snake_case ;)

(This review is as of lesson #104, so I haven't seen any Django sections yet. I'll update this review later...)
results.content_html:
(My background: iOS developer (5y+), very unexperienced in web development, built a few Flash websites 10y ago)

I really liked the first part of this course, the general introduction to web development, useful tools, and the introduction to JavaScript. It was straightforward, easy and fun for me to follow along!

But I did not like the introduction to Python (parts one and two) very much:
- the explanations, examples, and exercises are not chosen and structured very well. Sometimes language features are used out of the blue without much of an explanation. Everything feels a bit like random. Sometimes very basic things are repeated again and again (like the difference between a string and an integer), while more complicated stuff like "why and how to use a lambda expression?" does not get as much attention.
- It's also not at all a good introduction to OOP in general or good programming practices. It only touches these topics in an unstructured, and a bit amateurish way.
- the 'code challenges' (homeworks) are few, and not well chosen. E.g. the 'simple game' exercise does not focus on practicing the things covered in the previous lessons, but on the tricky game logic.
- the instructor probably writes much more JavaScript code than Python, since he intuitively always writes camelCase instead of snake_case ;)

(This review is as of lesson #104, so I haven't seen any Django sections yet. I'll update this review later...)

results.content: Once into the final and biggest part of the course (Django), the instructor  became very hard to follow. It seemed he was speeding through the meat of the course here ( 6 sections on Django ).  Explanations were very vague.  At one section he used "user" for a class, a function, a variable, and a dictionary key:value.  Keep in mind that all these "user" names linked to each other in different files making it very hard to follow which "user" was doing what.  I can't recommend this course.

results.content: The lecturer is clear and the course is paced well for a total beginner. I've edited this review for those reading who might be doing this course in 2020-06 and beyond - as I am. This course was created about 3 years ago, and I've experienced some frustrations due to MacOS upgrading from Bash to Zsh to run commands in the console/terminal and Django syntax evolving  e.g. 'url' being replaced with 'path' in the url mapping files. Bootstrap is referred to often, and that too has evolved since the course creation e.g. a class like 'navbar-link' has become 'nav-link', etc. These small syntax  variations will cause frustration for some, but it also forces you to search for and engage with the most current online content regarding HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, Bootstrap, and your OS's command line syntax - which can only be a good thing.
results.content_html: The lecturer is clear and the course is paced well for a total beginner. I've edited this review for those reading who might be doing this course in 2020-06 and beyond - as I am. This course was created about 3 years ago, and I've experienced some frustrations due to MacOS upgrading from Bash to Zsh to run commands in the console/terminal and Django syntax evolving e.g. 'url' being replaced with 'path' in the url mapping files. Bootstrap is referred to often, and that too has evolved since the course creation e.g. a class like 'navbar-link' has become 'nav-link', etc. These small syntax variations will cause frustration for some, but it also forces you to search for and engage with the most current online content regarding HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, Bootstrap, and your OS's command line syntax - which can only be a good thing.

Great course though thanks

results.content:
The exercises go from too easy to impossible to accomplish with the tools and knowledge provided.  "Just google it" is not acceptable, we're supposed to be learning how to both write and read code.  Everything here is shortcuts and no meaningful depth to actually do these things yourself.  One of the most infuriating courses I've taken on udemy.

No one minds tough exercises but the ones posed here are straight up unfair to beginners.  This is made more galling because often times the solutions involve functions and methods that were never actually taught.

results.content: It's a pretty good course to get an overview of these languages, but it is out of date and needs to be updated to reflect changes to Bootstrap and, in particular, Django. The code the course gives does not always work with current versions of Django, which is a nuisance. Best practices also seem to have changed slightly (specifically regarding URL handling), so look up updated info on that if you're taking this course. Would not recommend as the only Django course you take, but it's a nice overview of full stack development to get you started.

This is a great course indeed. Upon following the content for 5 days, I can already write basic apps and combine them with my current knowledge. I downloaded the most up-to-date version of Django and haven't had any major problems.  

The only downside so far has been the outdated parts of the course, which are limited to url's (and regular expressions) in my experience. But the documentation, stackoverflow and Django Girls are more than enough to cover the problems related to version mismatches.

results.content:
The course contains a lot of new and useful concepts for me and I'm grateful to Jose for creating the course. And after the course I feel I can make a simple Django project of my own, but of course I am not confident in Django.  
But I would like there would be more explanations in the Social Media Site Clone Project not just retyping the code, but make the detail explanation of each method and concept with a link to documentation for self studying. Some questions about the course content remained unanswered. 
Also, I wish the course contained more Home Work especially in the Django section of the course and It would be great if Jose update the course. The course was created in 2017 and some methods and concepts are obsolete in it. 
I recommend the course for studying the basic concept of the web development with the Django framework

results.content:
I'm very impressed with this course. I have quite a bit of scripting experience with PowerShell and VBScript, but I wanted to gently move myself into web application development and APIs.

Through my research, I decided that because Python would be a good fit for adding to my scripting languages, Django would be ideal to branch off of from there.

This course is great. Specifically, the progression. It very logically moves through what you need to know, piece by piece, and then ties it all together in a nice bow.
results.content_html:
I'm very impressed with this course. I have quite a bit of scripting experience with PowerShell and VBScript, but I wanted to gently move myself into web application development and APIs.

Through my research, I decided that because Python would be a good fit for adding to my scripting languages, Django would be ideal to branch off of from there.

This course is great. Specifically, the progression. It very logically moves through what you need to know, piece by piece, and then ties it all together in a nice bow.

results.content:
I like that although this is primarily a Django course, there was enough lectures on HTML, CSS, JavaScript and Python to give context on how Django relates to these other concepts.
  
The material is presented in a well-organized fashion so before learning the more complex concepts there are smaller simpler pieces taught first. Then the more complex concepts are built on the simpler pieces.

results.content: The instructor is very knowledgeable... almost too knowledgeable. He does a lot without explanation of why or how. The different projects switch from creating a view one way to another, so it's hard to practice yourself. On the topic of practice.... there is none. You don't get a chance to really try and develop a portion of the application yourself and compare against the instructor's code. He says here's what we are going to do and does it. The course would be a lot better if, for the projects, he gave a detailed explanation of what you should try and do in a video (ie set up a model/form/route), told you to pause and try it, and then you could compare what you did with what he did.
results.content_html: The instructor is very knowledgeable... almost too knowledgeable. He does a lot without explanation of why or how. The different projects switch from creating a view one way to another, so it's hard to practice yourself. On the topic of practice.... there is none. You don't get a chance to really try and develop a portion of the application yourself and compare against the instructor's code. He says here's what we are going to do and does it. The course would be a lot better if, for the projects, he gave a detailed explanation of what you should try and do in a video (ie set up a model/form/route), told you to pause and try it, and then you could compare what you did with what he did.

results.content:
The lessons are great even though I have to struggle a bit. Overall, the course content is thorough and easy to follow.. Q and A sessions are very helpful. Thanks.

This course was intense for me even with someone with an engineering background. There is so much material and steps to follow. The great thing about this course is that there are numerous resources available to you online. However, debugging some of the notes was nerve racking, but I guess that is part of the process of being a developer. I plan to continue my quest for knowledge, but I still have a long way to go to be comfortable in building websites. 

I will start off building simple sites until I can master the essentials. Thanks again.

regards,

Demayne

results.content:
If anyone wants to learn about Either Front end ,Back End or full stack Web development or just Python Language this is the best starting point for them. 
Here is my short story ,I am basically a Mechanical Engineer, and I had "Zero" Knowledge about Programming. After watching his Tutorials on JS and Python now I'm fan of the instructor.Loved his patience in making all those videos ,teaching each and every small things Perfectly so that students of different Paces can understand the concepts.
Now, I am interested in Machine Learning, But I need a lot of time to get a good Hold on Web Development , someday I will surely learn that too. In the end i just wanna say ,Don't think too much on whether to buy this course or not this is absolutely amazing.
English is not my First Language ,so please mind some mistakes.
Thanks again for this wonderful content  JP.

results.content: This course is fantastic. Jose instructs so well with no wasted time. I have just started Django. My head exploded with the Game of War exercise in Python, but I'll need much more practice before I can code something that complicated. It was expected. Other than that, the rest has been easy to follow. As I'm finished now, there was a lot to learn. Everything is here and as stated, really well instructed by Jose. My brain just can't remember is all, but for each topic, I've coded and example so it makes a great reference. This is the highest recommended course I have ever taken. Kudos to Jose.

results.content: Good instruction and support throughout the course - loads of different technologies were introduced and explained to the right level, and any bugs were easy to troubleshoot after a quick look on the extensive Q&A section. I liked the exercises as they often encouraged you to think about the previous material in a different way. The Django section is a little heavy at first but becomes familiar towards the end, and enables me to create and host an entire web page from scratch, using all the different technologies required to do so. I came from a starting point of just knowing Python. Thanks Jose!

The course is extremely well constructed, very clear in explanation and I highly recommend for first year computing science students (from whatever pr. language background)

From what I read so far many inexperienced people are having issues with Atom and I swapped to PyCharm which is much more easier to configure in any case compared to Atom (seriously I tried a lot ).
Except that the content is perfect, information clear so no matter what I highly recommend!

results.content: As a complete beginner to development, I find this ambitious course very challenging.  I like Jose's variety of courses and have learned a lot from him. The front-end material (HTML, CSS, Bootstrap, Java) can be conceptually understood fairly easily.  The back-end Django portions are difficult to conceptually understand.  I think Django itself needs more visual, conceptual explanations put out there. I'm thinking lectures on understanding the big picture of the Django conceptual framework will help give meaning to the code and help in understanding how all the various Django folders and files are linked and interrelated.  The Django material frustrated me and killed my course momentum.  As for course exercises, my suggestion is that all exercises should start out easy and then progress in difficulty.  Otherwise, starting with difficult exercises kills motivation. It's similar to starting a game on the hardest skill level...kills your motivation to play further.  I guess I'll grind through the Django lectures and hope there is meaning, understanding and light at the end of the tunnel.
results.content_html: As a complete beginner to development, I find this ambitious course very challenging. I like Jose's variety of courses and have learned a lot from him. The front-end material (HTML, CSS, Bootstrap, Java) can be conceptually understood fairly easily. The back-end Django portions are difficult to conceptually understand. I think Django itself needs more visual, conceptual explanations put out there. I'm thinking lectures on understanding the big picture of the Django conceptual framework will help give meaning to the code and help in understanding how all the various Django folders and files are linked and interrelated. The Django material frustrated me and killed my course momentum. As for course exercises, my suggestion is that all exercises should start out easy and then progress in difficulty. Otherwise, starting with difficult exercises kills motivation. It's similar to starting a game on the hardest skill level...kills your motivation to play further. I guess I'll grind through the Django lectures and hope there is meaning, understanding and light at the end of the tunnel.

results.content:
No references to major updates of Django (namely Django 2 and Django3). There was no clear heads-up of the depreciated workflow and its extend of incompatibility in regards to the newer Django versions. Helpful advice on how to make depreciated code work with the newer versions seems nowhere to be found. 
Throughout the course, there are some faulty lecture notes (e. g. the description on the "War" card game) as well as missing critical information on coding in a pythonic way (e. g. on error-handling and why there shouldn't ever be exceptions without declared error types). Nothing game-breaking but it suggests some lack of care on the content.
There are minor quirks of non-pythonic coding (e. g. defining classes with parentheses after the name of the class: 'class ClassName():').

The Bootstrap lectures were to a large part just copying and pasting code. I would be surprised if someone without prior knowledge on CSS outside of this course is able to benefit more from the course content than would be possible by just taking a quick look at the bootstrap documentation.

I was positively surprised by this course up until Section 16. But then ran into the problems of my first paragraph. I'll try to complete the course with the help of Google and might change my review based on that.
results.content_html:

Throughout the course, there are some faulty lecture notes (e. g. the description on the "War" card game) as well as missing critical information on coding in a pythonic way (e. g. on error-handling and why there shouldn't ever be exceptions without declared error types). results.content: Clear explanations of the basic stuff.  Some of the explanations are too quick.  There is a 25 min video, even though its relatively long, I feel like the instructor goes too fast.  Perhaps for that case the video should have been split in 4 parts of 12 minutes each.  Also some of the projects are too difficult for what is being taught here, maybe the difficulty should be gradually increased by adding more intermediate exercises before a 150 lines code one.
results.content_html: Clear explanations of the basic stuff. Some of the explanations are too quick. There is a 25 min video, even though its relatively long, I feel like the instructor goes too fast. Perhaps for that case the video should have been split in 4 parts of 12 minutes each. Also some of the projects are too difficult for what is being taught here, maybe the difficulty should be gradually increased by adding more intermediate exercises before a 150 lines code one.

results.content: Great course. Jose pays particular attention to explaining things instead of just showing them and telling you to use them without understanding. The material is vast. If you are really willing to push the limits of your knowledge - do the exercises on your own without peeking in the solutions. This way you can get better really fast. Certainly can recommend and actually 2 of my acquaintances does this course as well for the above reason.

results.content: Really clear and concise. Good presenter. Very good content. Overall, I think this program is excellent.  Note of caution, there is a tendency in some of the later lectures to jump into more advanced code. He does a good job of walking you through it, but you may want to purchase his Mastering Python course to complement this program. Everything in this course has been straightforward and applicable to designing my own application.

results.content: Overall, the course is great. As someone who has taken far too many coding courses, the explanations here are clear and relevant. There have been a few cases now where the content feels rushed (i.e. limited explanation, lack of updates, etc.) that definitely hinder the content. While I completely understand there is a learning curve for anyone and that using google to solve problems for any programmer is a necessity, I have become frustrated when the videos are no longer relevant (with no indication on where to go / what to do) or what a solution is rushed through. Thankfully, I have had other experiences with python, javascript, etc. that I did not fall completely behind, but also can not imagine some of the definitely other users have to go through to get up to speed because of a lack of information.

results.content:
I highly recommend this course for the following reasons:

1. Well Structured: I started this course with minimal coding experience and no web development experience. Although some sections were more difficult than others, I had no trouble learning the foundational concepts that led to a complete understanding of python and django because of the course organization.

2. Outstanding course instructor: Jose Portilla teaches not only python and django in this course, but also how to research answers for yourself. He uses an older version of django in the course, but it is not a problem because the course notes are clear and up to date, and he clearly explains where to find updated code in the django documentation. 

In conclusion, I learned more than I expected in this course, and I would recommend it to anyone wanting to learn Python, Django, and basic CSS/HTML.

results.content:
Awesome course, i've been wanting to get into django to make my own portfolio site with something to show, but so far had a hard time finding a decent django tutorial, at least until i found this course.

He coverse everything, from a 'Front-end' crash-course to actually getting into django and learning the basics.

Only downside i found so far is: some videos are a little bit too long for my taste (>20 min), could easily split them in 2 videos at the cost of having more lessons in the course.

Also i would like to suggest adding a quiz for each section, that way people with experience will know what lessons they can easily skip and which ones they have to take.

Last but not least, django itself is a bit complex, so at first explanations may sound confusing for some people, hang in there, go through the django level 1 section a couple times and you'll get the hang of it ;)

results.content: A fairly comprehensive course on web development. It covers almost everything you need to know as a beginner, except database. Although after the initial 30% or so, the course degenerates into a "watch as I code" YouTube series. In many of the later videos, the instructor simply codes out entire chunks of the project without much explanation of what he is doing, nor does he show you what it would look like in the browser until some 100 lines of code.

results.content:
I still have a couple of modules to actually finish, but just wanted to say that I really enjoyed the course.

Jose seems like a really friendly and patient guy and I really appreciated that he repeated how to do things in Django (e.g. beginning projects from scratch even if it had been explained before).

I'm still definitely missing a lot of information, but, as Jose cared to highlight several times, it's about getting a good enough overview that then we fill be comfortable filling in the blanks ourselves with the documentation available (e.g. the one for Django, which I'm also finding really useful).

Cheers Jose!

results.content:
Excellent course! I liked that all of the concepts were first explained by themselves then were reinforced in the two final projects. The instructor speaks very clearly and is easy to understand (this is not the case for all Udemy instructors). 

I found that pausing the videos and manually typing the code myself (as opposed to simply copy/pasting form the course notes) helped me to better understand the concepts. This also introduced my own typos in the code, debugging my errors was very helpful as well.

I definitely recommend this course to anyone who wants to get involved with Full Stack development using Python/Django.

results.content: Hi, This professor knows what he's talking about. I hate giving under a 4 because Udemy and the rating system is harsh on that. Basically anything less is fail and this is not fail. This is good for beginners. But I can't stick with it. It's too tedious. I like to learn by diving into stuff. I didn't know any Html or CSS or JS before this course. I knew some python from another course and no django, but this course proved too tedious and slow even for the stuff I didn't know. I ended up taking a django course elsewhere. It's just a question of learning style but I like to dive in. Sometimes I find myself not ready for a certain course, but usually that's not the case, and when it is, I can take a more basic course but still I like to learn by doing and the style presented here is just too slow and gradual and you're not building anything actual, at least not at the point I stopped at. If this style works for you, then great. If not, there are other courses. I'm the kind of guy that likes to play around with settings and features until I figure it out as well as build stuff, so this is killing me!!!

results.content:
So far, the course is going well. It's a great course for anybody who wishes to learn web development from scratch to the point that they can manage a pretty decent website. If you are an enthusiastic self learner, you will be able to become a slightly advanced web developer by accessing the required documentations. 

However, I have found that every time we get into slightly complex topics, the instructor loses the required clarity. For example, in certain exercise solution videos, he tells us what the particular line of code does but he skips explaining how it does so. To understand this, I need either visit the Q&A in hopes that somebody else has addressed the issue or use trial and error method to play around with the code and understand the logic. 

Additionally, at many instances, the solutions contain unnecessary code lines which people have addressed in the Q&A multiple times and the instructor acknowledges it but does not edit it in the course video or in the resource material. I find this slightly problematic because if I try to understand the code by myself before I visit the Q&A. I waste a lot of time and then realize that a particular line of code was pointless. Even if I realize it in the first instance, since I am a beginner, I second guess myself and spend a lot of time making sure I understand everything well. 

All that being said, I rate the course 4/5 stars because in spite of my lengthy complaints, they are ones that can be overcome. The course content and structure itself is really good. I would definitely recommend it to any web development beginner especially if you are getting the course on a discount.

Even if I realize it in the first instance, since I am a beginner, I second guess myself and spend a lot of time making sure I understand everything well.

All that being said, I rate the course 4/5 stars because in spite of my lengthy complaints, they are ones that can be overcome. The course content and structure itself is really good. I would definitely recommend it to any web development beginner especially if you are getting the course on a discount.

results.content:
I love the introduction to Atom IDE on top of my experience with VS Code/Spyder in Anaconda.  I wish they'd add Atom to Anaconda...project!

In building my own applications, I am finding that there are still two pretty steep learning curves:
(1) Django developers' wacky setups across multiple Django versions.  A lot of extensible stuff doesn't work or is hard to customize.  That's not a discredit to the course, just wish there was...not sure. 

(2) A deeper exploration of deployment - the collect static, using CDN's in deployment, and maybe Jenkins or setting up git versioning in development.  Building tests would be great too!  Maybe this all belongs in an advanced Django course...
results.content_html:
I love the introduction to Atom IDE on top of my experience with VS Code/Spyder in Anaconda. I wish they'd add Atom to Anaconda...project!

In building my own applications, I am finding that there are still two pretty steep learning curves:
(1) Django developers' wacky setups across multiple Django versions. A lot of extensible stuff doesn't work or is hard to customize. That's not a discredit to the course, just wish there was...not sure.

(2) A deeper exploration of deployment - the collect static, using CDN's in deployment, and maybe Jenkins or setting up git versioning in development. Building tests would be great too! Maybe this all belongs in an advanced Django course...

results.content:
Generally a good course.  Jose Portilla does an excellent job at putting together a very thoughtful and well-planned course.  Overall I would recommend it.

However, there are a few areas with room for improvement:
1. Javascript section needs to be reworked to focus more on common operations people try to achieve with javascript (form controls and checks, graphing, on-click interaction.
2. Django section is now (a little) outdated as the package has released a new version that is much more user friendly.
3. The clone projects were okay, but more attention should have been paid to explain how to access the models and return data from them.  IT really seemed like this part was a bit rushed while previous sections were a bit slow.

I have taken Jose Portilla's Machine Learning Bootcamp, and highly recommend it.
results.content_html:
Generally a good course. Jose Portilla does an excellent job at putting together a very thoughtful and well-planned course. Overall I would recommend it.

However, there are a few areas with room for improvement:
1. Javascript section needs to be reworked to focus more on common operations people try to achieve with javascript (form controls and checks, graphing, on-click interaction.
2. Django section is now (a little) outdated as the package has released a new version that is much more user friendly.
3. The clone projects were okay, but more attention should have been paid to explain how to access the models and return data from them. IT really seemed like this part was a bit rushed while previous sections were a bit slow.

I have taken Jose Portilla's Machine Learning Bootcamp, and highly recommend it.

results.content:
The content and scope of the course is excellent and the tutor explains the topics well. I would have given it 5*, but for one issue (which is most likely down to my lack of computer science knowledge).
 
This issue is that while I can now understand the programming concepts covered in this course, I still do not have the ability to think like a programmer and to, therefore, start resolving problems myself. 

I think I would have greatly benefited from lectures that addressed the thought processes of planning the projects undertaken and not just the coding aspect. For example, what thought processes could I follow to identify the number of classes required and what each class should contain, how many apps should be created, what html pages would be required, etc?

This does not detract from what was otherwise a very well structured and delivered course.
results.content_html:

results.content:
This is the perfect course for someone who wants to learn Django and build web apps. It's very practical and easy to understand. You will have a good idea how Python and Django actually work by doing real-time apps. There could be some more explanation on how different files coordinate with each other. Like urls.py,settings.py,etc. I felt a bit confusing how to start on my own when building an app.
Jose is really good instructor. You can reach him for any errors/bugs n your practice session. He probably will reply you within a day depending on your timezone.

I did the course with pre-knowledge about html, css and python(beginner). Besides Django it was great to learn all the small steps/topics on the way: like python (for me refresh of beginner stuff plus level two stuff), bootstrap, jquery etc. .

I was really surprise on how much content was offered in this course and the great documentation as well. Once I've reached the parts about Django I thought it will be only a few lessons about it, but instead it was like a hole new course, excellent!  Also all questions that I had throughout the process were quickly answered by the instructor. 

With all my new knowledge I'm now confident enough to start my own projects and portfolio! I consider this awesome since the Django framework is really complex and not easy to get in to.

results.content:
Overall, a very nice course to learn web development with Django. Learned a lot from this course. A lot of stuff is covered & the easy pace of the instructor makes it comfortable to follow the stuff (except the pace is slightly too fast in the clone projects). But, good job overall! I now feel confident to handle Django project independently! Thanks Jose.

A suggestion, especially for the Social Site Clone project, since, it brings together a lot of stuff learned earlier in the course & some more:-
Be better if the material is organized wrt building up the application piece by piece. What I mean is - instead of coding all the stuff and finally debugging, it would be better to follow the real world approach - build each part of the application (including required model/s, view, url, form, etc.), then debugging/running to get that part to work, & then moving on to the next part. I feel, this will help the student to grasp the process better & see the application grow piece-by-piece.

Again, a nice experience overall & I would happily recommend this course to anyone!

results.content: I have completed the 2020 Complete Python Bootcamp course by Jose, prior to beginning this course. I have experience working with Bootstrap, HTML and CSS, but this course is really consolidating a lot of my knowledge. The course is comprehensive and provides pointers to all the relevant documentation for the programming languages and frameworks discussed. Currently I am just over half-way through the course and the only minor improvement I would suggest, is that I would have appreciated a little more information regarding how to scale images in Bootstrap. Jose provides a solid grounding in Bootstrap, but a 'working with images section', maybe introducing GIMP and explaining scaling images utilizing Bootstrap's built-in functionality (and CSS) would have saved me some frustration (and as I am only half-way through the course, this might get covered later on). Jose does provide more than enough direction for the learner to explore Bootstrap and as I say, the aforementioned would just be a bonus to a course that feels ridiculously cheap for what I am learning (it must be stated that I purchased this course whilst it was on sale). I feel confident that by the time I have completed this course, I will have the ability to create functioning full stack websites. Another great course by Jose, he really knows how to pace and develop learning material.

Jose provides a solid grounding in Bootstrap, but a 'working with images section', maybe introducing GIMP and explaining scaling images utilizing Bootstrap's built-in functionality (and CSS) would have saved me some frustration (and as I am only half-way through the course, this might get covered later on). Jose does provide more than enough direction for the learner to explore Bootstrap and as I say, the aforementioned would just be a bonus to a course that feels ridiculously cheap for what I am learning (it must be stated that I purchased this course whilst it was on sale). I feel confident that by the time I have completed this course, I will have the ability to create functioning full stack websites. Another great course by Jose, he really knows how to pace and develop learning material.

results.content:
This is your course if you are absolute beginner in [web] programming!

I was not absolute beginner but experienced programmer and teacher when bought the course. I just wanted to learn Python and Django. I bought the course and I was amazed how fantastic job Jose is doing here in flattening absolute beginners way by teaching everything needed to web app programming. From zero to hero is not marketing talk here - it is simple truth!

Student will learn html, Atom (editor), Bootstrap (ui easy way), Javascript, DOM, JQuery and - finally - Python and Django.

Really good investment: if you want to get value for your money, just buy this one!

And Jose: great job - thank you!

results.content:
As Always with Jose, great course! 

Great Instructor for a large topic. However, I would like to point out that the bootstrap section might be a little out of date. For that, I recommend learning Boostrap directly from the documentation on their website. It won't stop you from learning Django which is the main topic of this course, but you will have to spend extra time to understand the up to date version of Boostrap.

Only half way and I got a really good introduction to HTML, CSS and Javascript.

If you have any doubt about this instructor, I can tell you from my previous experiences that he is the best instructor for any python related topics. I took the python bootcamp and python for Finance a few month back and i really feel comfortable coding in python now!

Thank you Jose!

Found this course to be really helpful in getting a better understanding of Django.  I have tried some other Django tutorials on YouTube previously but they just walk through the steps to build a site without explaining why so clearly.   I feel confident that I can go and build my own site now.  

I liked that you repeated the steps for creating new projects from start to finish each time. I'm one of those people who can only absorb through hands on practice so it really helped me and for the last few projects I was able to go ahead and set things up without needing to follow along.

results.content:
This is a very robust and thoroughly presented web development course. It is by far the most detailed course I have taken in web development.
However, it would have been nicer if the course was brought up to date in terms of the Django version used here. I had a few hiccups with version conflict but nothing a few Q&A  and Google searches couldn't fix. 
Thank you so much Mr Jose Portilla and thanks Udemy for this great course.

results.content: In general I think the course is good. I skipped the Python parts as I already have done the separate Python course. My main reason for this course was the Django stuff, and I am not very impressed on how the cloning projects were structured. For me it would be better if we were to build the front-end first, and then add the links and functions to the site so you would get a better understanding what you are actually working with. It would also be nice to get some milestone assignments to try for ourselves, as there is in the Python course.  I used latest Python (3.8) and Django (3.0) versions  when doing this course, and it was only small changes I had to do to make things work (mainly using path instead of url in the urls.py files, and static instead of staticfiles in the templates).

results.content: This course is an OK course for a total beginner. People with some background in programming, and I am not talking about senior devs, I am talking about people with basic knowledge about object-oriented programming and web development will find this course way too shallow. So if you find yourself in the second category, I strongly suggest you follow Django's official tutorial as it covers pretty much everything covered in this course related to Django. The same applies to all other parts like Javascript and HTML. If you do find yourself overwhelmed with the official documentation of the things I mentioned above, you will probably enjoy this course. However, if you did manage to complete all those official tutorials on you own, I strongly suggest you to not buy this course as you'll be disappointed. I am giving this course 3/5 because in my opinion, the instructor should have made it clear that this course was for beginners only. However, I do recommend this course to people wanting to get into web development who have absolutely no background in it.

results.content: Jose Portilla delivers outstanding material and superb performance in his well researched, world class lectures.  I've taken several of his courses: Python Bootcamp; Data Science and Machine Learning in Python, R, Scala & Spark (3 separate courses); and PostgreSQL Bootcamp. results.content: This is a quality course, great for beginners, might be tough for complete novices. Come in with just a little background on python and/or website languages to make this class a breeze. I love Jose's repetitive nature which is great for ingraining content. I was so used to making Django projects and then apps because we made so many from the start (as opposed to modifying one long running app) that I had a lot of the command line calls memorized by the end.

results.content: Lectures are great, but I wish there were more exercises (I mean tons and tons of exercises, not just a few challenges) to assimilate and solidify our understanding. So much material that you end up forgetting what you saw 2 lectures before, despite the notes. Also, I wish that the few challenges/activities provided used more cumulative material, rather than just the concept taught during the current chapter. That would force the student to re-use earlier concepts that would otherwise be forgotten. For example, by the time we started the Django lessons, I couldn't remember half of the material in JS. Would be cool to have many exercises asking to use html, css, js, dom, python and django all combined together, before actually getting to the clone project.
results.content_html: Lectures are great, but I wish there were more exercises (I mean tons and tons of exercises, not just a few challenges) to assimilate and solidify our understanding. So much material that you end up forgetting what you saw 2 lectures before, despite the notes. Also, I wish that the few challenges/activities provided used more cumulative material, rather than just the concept taught during the current chapter. That would force the student to re-use earlier concepts that would otherwise be forgotten. For example, by the time we started the Django lessons, I couldn't remember half of the material in JS. Would be cool to have many exercises asking to use html, css, js, dom, python and django all combined together, before actually getting to the clone project.

results.content:
Really good so far, Enjoyed the front end part. Still managed to learn a little about python after 4 years in the python part 2. Currently working through Django.

Edit: After completing most of the course I have dropped my rating a bit. I enjoyed most of the course but I found the social media clone project to not flow as well as the rest of the content. I think because we were coding out a premade thing in chunks, it made it very difficult to see what progress was being made at any point because there was something missing right up until the end. Debugging then became a bit more difficult because I couldn't test things along the way. 

Overall I think this is a really good course that falls down a little bit at the last project. Even though this is an earlier version of django and bootstrap, if you have programming experience going into this then it should be possible to read the docs and see what's changed.

Thanks Jose!

results.content:
This course starts off pretty solid. The frontend portion in particular is very helpful. Once the course starts the django portion though, things start to really fall apart. To begin, the django material is very outdated and needs serious revision. There are a number of issues where entering the code in the code alongs breaks. Checking to documentation for django reveals that some of these were deprecated years ago.

Another issue is when the course enters forms and models for django the pace and the depth of the review is insufficient, particularly the model forms section. Telling the student to check the documentation is appropriate in many cases as learning coding is about exploration and experimentation on the part of the student. However, giving the students little to no guidance makes one wonder, why pay for a course at all if you just have to fight through the documentation with little direction.

results.content:
Mr. Portilla goes through a lot of material and I'm sure it's taken a ton of time for him to put everything together.  He teaches a lot of advanced topics which you don't see much of elsewhere and the course starts pretty strong but as you go deeper into the course, a lot of the material seems rushed and the syntax is typed without a clear explanation as to what's going on.  Overall it was a good course, but it falls a bit short.  

I've taken some other courses where there was less material but they were very clearly explained and as a result I do not regret them at all. 
 However, this class could use some work as I feel there were plenty of hours of my time which I had to go back and forth between reading the Django Tutorials, asking in the Q&A and other forums for help on topics that were glossed over.  

Some materials for example which I really wish were elaborated on include:

The use of TabularInLines, Slugs, OneToMany, ManyToMany relationships, etc....

results.content: I've just started on the bootstrap section. For me the course so far has been very clear. I could follow along well with the concepts and using Atom is so easy (autocomplete!). I'm curious whether by the end I'll be able to create the webapplication I'm going for, since beginner classes tend to not go in depth in enough to create meaningful projects, but with this course I'm so far very satisfied. A lot of different material is covered and I really like that it covers more than one programming language, in order to give you the functionality of being able to create a web applicaiton. I.e. it's not just "how to do Django" and "oh by the way you should learn all this other stuff like javascript too, but we won't cover that here".

results.content:
The course was excellent overall, and explained Django concepts very well. I am leaving a 4.5 star rating instead of a 5 star because:
1. It is outdated, and fixes are necessary such as using path() instead of url()
2. Rushed a lot at the end, and didn't really stop to explain concepts like the course did in the beginning and the middle
But other than that, this course is excellent. I do recommend for people that consider buying this that you have at least a little bit of prior coding experience (preferably Python), as it will definitely help you with Django. 
In conclusion, I would definitely recommend this course!
Thank you to everyone who was involved in the production of this course!
