I don't like the fact that it keeps asking me so often; I've taken longer courses that just ask once near the beginning and when I click to ask at the end they wait. Not sure if Udemy changed or this is a setting you did, but please change if possible. 

Beyond the annoying prompt to rate so often, this would probably receive a better rating, so if I get a reminder at the end I will update. My impressions so far are that this is really better for someone with at least some code experience. I don't feel that the early stuff is covered extensively enough or with enough practice to really help someone become competent on their own. 

Despite that, the course is solid and I look forward to completing it for a more thorough review.

results.content: This course is OK, but 2 things make this course less compelling.  First off, too much material.  Trying to do all front-stack items in one course is way, way too much.  Unfortunately, the hard part of learning Django (the ORM) is lost in CSS and custom fonts.  This needs to be 2 or 3 courses with focus on individual elements of front-stack development.  Secondly, the content is out of date and Django, Bootstrap, and CSS have all changed.

results.content: Hi José. Thank you for this complete course on Django. The Blog Clone Project was amazing and we could experience how it is to create a working webpage/webserver from scratch. As mentioned in your very first lessons, the code might have looked a bit outdated. So, that's why I spent a couple of minutes more to finish each lesson since I had to search for different ways of solving the compatibility issues and make the code run properly. I strongly recommend this course to everyone interested in a complete full stack development experience.

results.content:
TLDR: Good, but had an extra section on migrating projects from Django 1.1x to 2.x+ been added, I'd give 4.5-5 stars.

A great overview of HTML, CSS, Bootstrap, and JavaScript, followed by a detailed look at Django. Jose does a great job at expressing what you really need to know, without drowning in details, which is great. That said, outdated versions are my biggest complaint. Particularly due to the fact that Django 2 (taught in 1.10.5) and Bootstrap 4 (taught in 3) represent fairly significant changes from what's taught in the course.
results.content_html:

results.content:
This course has really got me moving with Python and Django. I thought I had a good understanding of the basics of Python, this turned out not to be true. The parts on Class inheritance were particularly useful. 

I thought the final assignment was a bit muddled. I felt by the end both me and the instructor were just trying to power through without fully understanding how everything links together. My understanding of how different apps link together is still fairly weak. I think it would have been good to do more without the ListModel, DetailModel, etc before moving on to them.

Overall I am happy with the course, I've learnt a lot and as someone who's been working with PHP for years, it's given me enough to get past the beginning of Django and start work out how to build whatever I want.

I don't have any hesitations in recommending this course to others though.

results.content: I already had some basic knowledge of frontend and Python, so I started the course on the Django part and my review is thus referred only to that. Overall I liked the course very much, but I would suggest a few ideas to improve it. Often too much code is written without looking at the immediate result, which can create some confusion since only at the end the website will be displayed and the relation between single features and the code to implement them becomes quite unclear. Also the instructor is often forced to say something like "I'm writing this code, which I'll explain later", that might be quite confusing as well. I feel like dividing the projects "by implemented feature" and providing versions of the project code that follow the development instead of a single "final result" could be better (even though I agree it looks less like real world development). Anyway, overall my impression was very positive and I congratulate with Jose for the great course!

This course was fantastic.  Jose presents all materials clearly, and with just the right amount of detail.  I learned much more from this course than from any other books or materials on Django. 

Most important, I think this finally gave me a foundation in understanding exactly what "Full Stack" development is all about.

Also, what you learn here can be applied to other languages.  The Front End portion of the course is worth the price alone.  You can then take what you learn and apply it to C# or Java or PHP, etc.  

Thanks!

results.content:
Finally got to the Django section of the course to find it is at least a year out of date. The course actually links to the official Django tutorial, which now does things differently! All the non-Django front-end stuff (first half of the course) is ok but necessarily broad and brief (like all the 'complete...' courses on Udemy).
Teaching assistants answer some of the questions on Q&A, however they can be a bit abrupt, and occasionally unhelpful (I saw one student get told to look it up themselves as it would help their problem-solving skills!). 
As with all courses which try to cover an entire technology stack in one go, the learning curve is difficult to get right and you will probably find yourself using many other resources to help you as you go.  I'm genuinely surprised this is as highly rated as it is.
results.content_html:

results.content:
I learned a great deal from this course.  The lessons are broken down in a  coherent and manageable way.  I enjoyed the video lessons.  The instructor is very knowledgeable and explains concepts very clearly.  I would highly recommend this course to anyone that is interested in learning full stack Django web development.  

There have been version updates to Django that render some of the specific information in these lectures incorrect.  That fact and the instructor's decision to switch to a Mac for the final project make completing the final project a challenge.  To give an example, the way you import reverse has changed. A note should be added at the front of the lectures that are affected by these changes.  

All in all, this is a great course with an outstanding instructor!
results.content_html:
I learned a great deal from this course. The lessons are broken down in a coherent and manageable way. I enjoyed the video lessons. The instructor is very knowledgeable and explains concepts very clearly. I would highly recommend this course to anyone that is interested in learning full stack Django web development.

There have been version updates to Django that render some of the specific information in these lectures incorrect. That fact and the instructor's decision to switch to a Mac for the final project make completing the final project a challenge. To give an example, the way you import reverse has changed. A note should be added at the front of the lectures that are affected by these changes.

All in all, this is a great course with an outstanding instructor!

Thank you Jose for such a fantastic course! I have to say that from the moment I started the course to now I have learnt so much. I have learn about HTML, CSS, BOOTSTRAP, JQUERY, DJANGO and so much more. 

It is definitely designed for beginners and the flow of the course is quite logical. You do not end up coming out an expert but it does give you solid grounding to start your research further.

IMPROVEMENTS: I had to skip games coding lectures for both Javascript and Python. I couldn't be bothered learning a new game and then learning a new language with it. I would definitely suggest simpler examples. Thank you once again.

results.content:
Great web development course! It's specially great if you are interesting or want to use django as your main framework for developing web applications, but it's certainly good for anyone interesting in web development.
I was really curious about Django so this has show me a lot about the power of it, plus, the first sections, with html, css, bootstrap, javascript and python (without django) are really good.
Jose is a great instructor, sometimes i had a doubt an he suddenly mentioned it. The Q&A forum is also good, you can find solutions or curious/interesting things.
Django is great, but sometimes it feels just like magic, so if you take this course and want to go further in web development with Django, remember that you have to keep researching, but this is a great starting point, and a huge reference! 
A great course, again, it's specially great if you are really curious about django or want to make it your main tool.
results.content_html:
Great web development course! It's specially great if you are interesting or want to use django as your main framework for developing web applications, but it's certainly good for anyone interesting in web development.
I was really curious about Django so this has show me a lot about the power of it, plus, the first sections, with html, css, bootstrap, javascript and python (without django) are really good.
Jose is a great instructor, sometimes i had a doubt an he suddenly mentioned it. The Q&A forum is also good, you can find solutions or curious/interesting things.
Django is great, but sometimes it feels just like magic, so if you take this course and want to go further in web development with Django, remember that you have to keep researching, but this is a great starting point, and a huge reference!
A great course, again, it's specially great if you are really curious about django or want to make it your main tool.

results.content:
Overall it's a helpful course with good information. The course is pretty fast paced so, although it says it's 36 hours of course material, be prepared for plenty of stop and go. Some of the concepts are also just presented and not really explained (especially in the django sections) so you need to spend some time researching why it is you're doing what you're doing. 

Additionally, the course is a tad bit out of date. At the time of recording django 1 was used and there have been some changes since the release of django 3. Luckily the course assistants are pretty helpful in the comments.

results.content:
The course is great. +30 hrs video, circa 200 lessons. It's huuuuge! 
It will lead you thru html, css, bootstrap, JavaScript, jQuery, DOM, Python, Django and even deployment!! TERRIFIC.

However  the course material is old. You have to tweak some part and lectures if you are used to deal with updated libs (django, bootstrap mostly).In first part of the course you have to tweak your code to recreate them using Bootstrap 5. But it's not so bad. But then I found the Django part to be hella hard.  It is based on 1.1 version. It's not dramtically different from the one  in use today, the 3, but the topic are quite complex, the explanation Jose is doing is very raught and then, the code and the folder structure doesn't match your work environment and you have to deal with Django documentation continuosly. It's a long and tiring process. Q&A are great but expect to deal with questions with over 20 answers since a lot of people are getting stuck for the reason above. I started this course with great determination but after like 50 and more hours into it, i start to feel tired and I am not understanding well what the hell is happening on django. 

Also to be honest the websites you are creating within the courses look stale and outdated, it doens't give you the idea of being creating something cool. 

Projects are "out of range" for their difficulty related to course material. I mean, mostly left to solve on your own without any particular preparation. This made me feel dumb. Luckily I found out I was not the one experiencing this. 
The course is mostly "watch me as I code and past strings from the notepad", and explanations of the "why" are not so much. In a lot of sections I had a better understanding reading a 5 minute answer from stack overflow than watching 1 hours of this video, that, in some parts, it's even more confusing than claryfing. 

I like Jose a lot and it's the third course of him I purchased but for this one i raccomrnd to wait for an update.

results.content:
This was a topic that I was approaching for the first time and I learnt a heck of a lot!  The front end sections were explained relatively well, but the back end sections seem much more complex and require a much more detailed explanation.

The first half of the course flowed well.  However, the pace of the second half of the course was too fast.  I think that it could be improved by spending more time explaining what is going on and less time ploughing through code.  For example, the addition of some lectures with flow diagrams or some other visualisation included as to how everything fits together would be helpful.

The instructor and support team is engaged and responsive and field questions excellently.  However, on this particular course, given the pace, there were just so many questions that I needed to ask.

Having finished the course now and learnt a lot, it does still feel necessary to go away and spend further time understanding Django and the flow of Django projects, before I am fully comfortable with the subject.

results.content:
Okay... I'm only at the CSS section of the course... when I reached my favorite lessons that I've come across... and I've taken over two hundred online courses over the past several years (it's my new hobby)... in this lesson...the instructor pointed out a 20-second portion of the video where he slipped up and mixed saying class instead of ID... 

I can't tell you how many courses I've seen where the instructor's added entire lines of code between sections that aren't on film that they never mention anywhere... leaving me to retrace my steps over and over again... until I finally watch the video again and realize what they changed... 

I appreciate that commitment to these courses... and look forward to digging in and start to learn the languages that I'm not already familiar with... I don't typically rate courses until I'm done... but... I don't know... so far... I feel comfortable with commiting to five stars!!!

results.content:
While I have taken several Django classes and have learned a lot on my own, the reason that I really liked this class is because not only does Jose show you HOW to do things, but he also explains WHY you do them.  The previous classes that I took simply told you what to do, but I truly didn't understand why we were doing it, which made it difficult to replicate on anything new or different and very frustrating when you want to make changes.

And, while the Django documents are very thorough, they are not easy to understand when you are first starting out.

I learned a lot in this class and I learned it in a way that will help me move forward easier.

B
results.content_html:

results.content: Half of the course is not about Django, but about the web fundamentals such as HTML, CSS, JS, etc, so it might be more beneficial to those without the basics. When I enrolled, I was hoping this course to cover deeply about Django, because I already know the basics. However, even just half of the course, the content is still good enough to help you get you going with the framework. After this course, I think I can start learning from the official Django documentation and from doing projects myself.
results.content_html: Half of the course is not about Django, but about the web fundamentals such as HTML, CSS, JS, etc, so it might be more beneficial to those without the basics. When I enrolled, I was hoping this course to cover deeply about Django, because I already know the basics. However, even just half of the course, the content is still good enough to help you get you going with the framework. After this course, I think I can start learning from the official Django documentation and from doing projects myself.

David

results.content:
The first part of the course, Web stuff:

The material has been straightforward and easy to follow, I look forward to finishing this series. 


Update 1:
I finished the first half of the course. Web and Python sections. I am getting stuck on the Django part. I think it may be my fault as the syntax provided by the course does not seem to work for me(specifically they use url(), i need to use path().) I am planning to continue learning Django through another course, and through the free Django tutorials and resume this course after I am more confident in my skills to complete the exercises. I still do like the professor and would recommend them.

Update 2:
A day later I figured out my problem is this course is set in Django 1.X. I am using Django 2.X. Some of the methods have become unsupported the url() is one of them.
results.content_html:
The first part of the course, Web stuff:

The material has been straightforward and easy to follow, I look forward to finishing this series.

Update 1:
I finished the first half of the course. Web and Python sections. I am getting stuck on the Django part. I think it may be my fault as the syntax provided by the course does not seem to work for me(specifically they use url(), i need to use path().) I am planning to continue learning Django through another course, and through the free Django tutorials and resume this course after I am more confident in my skills to complete the exercises. I still do like the professor and would recommend them.

Update 2:
A day later I figured out my problem is this course is set in Django 1.X. I am using Django 2.X. Some of the methods have become unsupported the url() is one of them.

results.content:
As a Python analytics programmer, I don't deal with front-end languages and this is definitely what I need.

I studied Django numerous times in the past but grew tired and confused since web development requires deeper understanding of the various web technologies that makes the framework possible.

This course gives a crash course on the holy trinity of front-end web development  and some Python basic concepts which made me fully reinforce my understanding on how Django works.

results.content: This course is useful and it gave me a start on Django. I am so thankful to the instructor. However, I feel it could be improved. The instructor just explains how to achieve certain tasks, but there is no explanation on why something works or any other details. In the Django section he just goes through the motions of making a project etc and it gets unengaging. The real world projects are really barebones and doesn't really inspire. Also I feel the naming of the lessons can be improved by giving a hint about the material instead of just naming them 'Django project 4, 5' etc

results.content:
A very good course on the basics of Django. Jose explains the material quite well, so it's easy to understand the individual components of Django project and how they relate to each other. Especially good point is that the individual components are first discussed separately on a very basic level and only in the final part of the course are they used to construct two simple clone sites, so that you get a clear idea of what you are doing.

I also appreciated that in the clone projects there were some mistakes made, so there was an opportunity to do some basic debugging.

There are couple of minor issues with this course, however:

1. Jose speaks a little bit too fast for a comfortable code along (at least for me - I got a plenty of typo-related errors just from trying to keep up). This can be remedied by decreasing the speed of the video, although it makes the speech sound a bit weird.

2. The course works with Django 1 which is a bit different from the latest version (Django 3). The difference is not that great, but you will occasionally get errors if you use only the videos for reference. This is especially true with respect to the clone projects that include a lot of front end stuff that no longer works (Bootstrap classes, glyphicons, etc.).

On the other hand, the course resources are fully updated to reflect changes mad in Django 3, so if you are stuck somewhere, it's usually a best course of action to compare the project with the relevant resource file. The differences are also treated and explained in the Q&A section, usually in considerable detail.

With these things in mind, it is an excellent course, which I would recommend for any beginner looking to learn Django framework.

results.content: Excelente curso! O instrutor é bastante didático e parece estar sempre atualizando o curso e fazendo correções. Minha única crítica será construtiva, motivo pelo qual dei 4 estrelas e meia. Na parte final, onde temos os projetos, acho que ficaria mais fácil acompanhar se fosse feito de forma diferente: ao invés de codificar o projeto inteiro, através de diversas aulas, e somente no final mostrar o resultado, acho que o mais didático seria "programar uma parte, mostrar o resultado", num ciclo mais iterativo. Fiquei bastante perdido e ansioso para ver o resultado final em cada projeto. Deixo aqui essa dica. De resto, o curso é muito bom, recomendo fortemente para quem quiser ter uma visão geral de como é ser um desenvolvedor full-stack usando django.

results.content: The course was a thorough and comprehensive introduction to the vast possibilities of using Django.  The content in the lectures built upon themselves very well.  One issue was that it used an older version of Django, which required me to search the Q&A or other online documentation to resolve breaking changes between the versions.  On the whole, I am quite pleased with the course and look forward to applying my new skills with other projects.

results.content:
Still amazing! It’s really hard to stop when my time for learning is up during the day. Django is the most challenging part for me so far. The explanation seems to be faster and perhaps less detailed compared to the previous lectures. This opinion might however be biased as I have some previous knowledge and experience in Python but I am a newbie to Django. Anyways, it is still easy to follow, logical and fun :)
--update--
Nearing the end of the course I found some flaws. The overall experience is still good, but I have the feeling that some of the rather important concepts are not discussed in details. Sometimes different approaches are used for solving similar problems without explaining the differences or explaining when to use which. It is confusing and in case you really want to understand the concepts, it requires tons of extra reading and searching.  I changed my rating from 5 to 4 as the level of real explanation dropped significantly when reaching the clone projects.

results.content:
The course is very well structured. Jose has a very clear understanding of the subject . I really liked building the final project applications. Every aspect of full stack development like html, css, javascript, jquery, python, using Django framework is touched upon. 
There is no in depth discussion of some of the topics but that could be found out with self study. However the course serves as a pointer and guideline for web development for beginners.

I would have liked a few more projects like building  e-learning platform(eg. Udemy) .
I thoroughly enjoyed the course and would like to take related courses by Jose.

results.content:
*Previous Knowledge*
HTML, CSS, Bootstrap: Basic 
Javascript, JQuery: None
Python: Intermediate
Django: None
**

The first half of the Bootcamp is almost perfect for someone that has little to no experience on html, css, Bootstrap, JS, JQuery. I found it enlightening and all the parts were explained very well. 

My issue here was the last parts of the Django Bootcamp. I understand that it is a very hard topic to cover, but that is exactly the reason why it should have been bigger and more detailed. Many parts are just code-alongs to the point that you lose track of what you know and what you don't. 
To be more specific, what annoyed me the most during the django lectures, was the last 2 big projects. It was the perfect chance for the instructor to review what we have learnt by briefly explaining every part, but he proceeded to a rushed code-along with lots of 'just refer to the previous lectures'. I mean, I know it is somewhere in the previous lectures, but exiting the lecture and start searching for the exact previous lecture and the exact moment that something was explained is very counter-productive. It was very frustrating at some point.

Tl;dr First part is nearly perfect for someone with no to little experience, last parts of Django Lectures should have been bigger, slower and more detailed.

results.content: this course seems to be obsolete with latest browser technology. One key lesson of this course is to run a js script file AFTER an html page is loaded. Their code works in their videos but when I run the same code in the same browser on my PC the script will always run before loading the page. I asked the instructor about this, got an answer from the assistant instructor saying he was "stumped" by this behavior (he actually reproduce it on his side), he did not know how to fix it. I wonder how often they review their courses to check if they are still compatible with latest browser version. Now I know why the course was on sale for $21, I will not ask for refund and keep it as general programming reference.  But would not rely on this as a learning tool.

results.content:
If you're trying to decide if this course is right for you, make sure you read this whole review.

First off, I'll tell you what this course is NOT. 

- This course will NOT make you a master of Python and Django. 
- This course will NOT allow you to get a job right after completing it.
- This course will NOT allow you to create a webapp on the same level as Instagram, twitch, etc. (at least not this course alone)

BUT, you notice I still gave it 5 stars.

That's because what this course WILL do is:

- Teach you the basic barebones of HTML, CSS, Javascript, and Python (including bootstrap and jquery).
- Teach you how to use Django to build a website/webapp with user accounts.
- Teach you how to incorporate HTML, CSS, and Javascript into Django on these websites.
- Introduce you to an instructor who really knows what he's doing, willing to make mistakes and work through them, help his students along the way, and even add new content.

So, you might be asking yourself, who is this course for?

This course is for beginners to intermediate programmers who want to start learning how to build a web app. It's for people who are not afraid to look things up and learn on their own. 

Jose teaches the fundamentals, but he also helps you learn how to go about looking things up, referencing the documentation, and more.

I went into this course because I am determined to build a web app for my company and Django seemed like the best route. I leave this course with the knowledge to start my project and get through at least a prototype I can then pass along. Did I learn everything I need? No, but I learned enough to know it can be done, and how to find information on the things I haven't yet learned.

It was an amazing course and he keeps adding more. He hinted at the next addition as a "fully functioning social network" and I'm very excited to see that!

Thank you, Jose!

results.content:
I would advice people that are interested in this course with not having any previous programming experience to allocate around 2 times the total 'video' content time for this course. Currently it's 32 hours but if you want to keep up with everything, do the exercises/projects you will need to spend at least double that time to do those exercises. 

So far it has surpassed my expectations, coming from an IT-student the content of this course definitely surpasses the things i have learned during my first year. I have been going through this course on 2x speed as i need to get a certificate and develop a small app for my final 3 credits to graduate. But from what i have done/seen so far this really gives you a good foundation as beginner.

results.content:
This was an excellent course starting from the basics of HTML/CSS and providing simple exercises building off what you learned while also forcing you to think a little more about creating a solution. If you want to become fluent in Python and Javascript this isn't the way but what you learn is enough to complete the assignments and build a basic website/web app. The Django section is well planned out, the instructor explains everything clearly - though some parts of Django could use a little more explanation.
One thing that I wish was in this course was a quick tutorial on developing REST APIs using Django Rest Framework. Other than that, this is an excellent resource for learning about Django.
results.content_html:
This was an excellent course starting from the basics of HTML/CSS and providing simple exercises building off what you learned while also forcing you to think a little more about creating a solution. If you want to become fluent in Python and Javascript this isn't the way but what you learn is enough to complete the assignments and build a basic website/web app. The Django section is well planned out, the instructor explains everything clearly - though some parts of Django could use a little more explanation.
One thing that I wish was in this course was a quick tutorial on developing REST APIs using Django Rest Framework. Other than that, this is an excellent resource for learning about Django.

results.content:
This is the second course that I choose from José (first one was 2020 Python Complete bootcamp from Zero to Hero whis was G R E A T).
And the reason why I chose him at first and why I choose him again this time is that he ACTUALLY EXPLAINS how things are done and why they work the way the do.
Jose proved me countless time how to TEACH properly, that's why I choose him again.
On top of that, he also includes a lot of material built in .pdf or other file formats that helps for better understanding and practice.
He truly shows that he cares and is very methodical builduing his courses and then explainin concepts.

I've just started 2 days ago, but I can't wait to finish this course as well!
-------------------------------------------------------------
UPDATE:
Well, now that I'm close to 70% completion of the course, I truly wish to keep the same calification but instead, I will downsize it 0.5 and explain my reasons:
1) Since it's been a while that the course has been built, many DJANGO lessons are outdated. This is a little inconvenient because some commands que uses are no longer useful in newer Django versions.
2) It's kind of difficult incorporating all the tools and knowledge that he gives from django lessons: he tells you (fair enough) that you should google it at Django documentation for further information (cool) but it get's the learning curve way higher.
3)"Practicing" Django still not very clear; for now is just like "code along" session. This is not like practicing with JS or Python; this is more like jungle code; coding in the dark, following José through the jungle and hope you don't get lost.
4) At this point you should become an expert at debugging django, but then again, this is actually something good, so instead of downsizing, this actually upsize grade.

In general, it's a good course, not so good as From Zero to Hero for Python, but good enough. José explains very good, that hasn't change.

results.content:
Fantastic course, Jose is a great teacher. Most of the time when I have a question e.g. "why do it this way?" he answers it moments later, like a psychic lol. Otherwise it's already been asked and answered in the extensive Q&A section.

Some parts were a bit tough for me having little to no programming skills going in, but those were either above-and-beyond knowledge that it's clear you can skip over (or cheat and watch the solutions lectures) if you want, or gets repeated and re-explained until you're familiar with it. 

The end of the course where you put it all together to make real websites is fun and rewarding. For how much I learned vs. how much I paid this class was an insanely good bargain.. highly recommend to anyone looking to get into web development or make a site but isn't sure where to start.

results.content:
I really enjoyed the course and learnt alot from the course especially the Django projects at the end of the course.

The course is very detailed and can be used by a beginner as a resource throughout their coding journey as it goes from HTML all the way through to using Django to create a complex project. The Django part is especially useful as it contains things like Class Based Views which streamline the whole process of  creating fun projects.

The only criticism I have is the Javascript sections of the course are very complex especially the coding challenges, this was my first time using Javascript and I felt the challenges were a major step up from the lessons. However this is a personal issue and I still gave the course 5 stars

results.content:
Excellent course and instructor, the course covers a lot of important topics for a full-stack web developer. 

A suggestion for improvement; in the clone projects, a short intro/description of the intention behind the class view methods/context (how are they going to be used) and template layout designs (Bootstrap grid) would be helpful - but this missing info forces the students to investigate more themselves, which is not a bad thing...
results.content_html:
Excellent course and instructor, the course covers a lot of important topics for a full-stack web developer.

A suggestion for improvement; in the clone projects, a short intro/description of the intention behind the class view methods/context (how are they going to be used) and template layout designs (Bootstrap grid) would be helpful - but this missing info forces the students to investigate more themselves, which is not a bad thing...

results.content:
Okay, i've been at odds with this course since i started it... lets be objective:
Cons: 
1- Django version is highly outdated
2- There is almost zero to none comments on propper coding, such as mentioning pep8...
3 - Everything up to Django Section feels rushed
4 - Instructors seem to be fed up at people like me who didn't take the course using the super old version of django.

Pros:
1-Since the course is so outdated, you will learn the hard way how to addapt this course to modern day. And you will do that a lot in this line of work.
2-Many helpful student comments will help you through debugging your errors.

Overall i feel many contents are not explained as they should have. 

They are thrown at your face as if you should understand them.
You shouldn't take this course if you are a begginer

results.content: When it comes to the front-end portion of the course, it does not cover lots of key concepts, for instance: the importance of semantics when it comes to HTML, CSS methodologies for code organization (BEM for instance), consistency in writing JS (no semicolons), introduction to frameworks and libraries before explaining core concepts (there's no point showing newcomers frameworks & libraries without explaining the principle behind them) . Sadly, many more important concepts are not explained which will prevent any newcomer to understand scalability and how to approach complex projects. This is definitely a decent introduction to these technologies, but it is way too simplistic.

results.content:
I learned a great deal in this course.  I would almost give the course a 5, but I felt like the Django lectures were sometimes a bit opaque.  That is, we were often told to type in a certain function name or field name, etc, without realizing that these were special names that were unique to Django. A little more elaboration from Jose about how Django was actually using these objects would have been nice . It would have reduced the feeling of "driving in the dark" in some of the lectures.   Jose did touch on this from time to time, but the explanations were sometimes too thin, I felt.

I don't want to harp too much on that, though.  We covered a very wide range of subjects in the course and I'm happy with how much I learned.

results.content:
This is a very comprehensive and well-organized course. Thanks Jose!


POSITIVES:
- The first half was a good precursor to the main meat.
- Touches on the necessary basics of html, css, js, and python just enough (but not too much) to be able to do django, well planned.
- I like the repetition of various things across projects and exercises, really allows some concepts to sink in. 


IMPROVEMENTS:
- During the django half,  the project videos turn into a "watch me code" copy/paste series which dampens focus & slows down learning.
-  I had to regularly go out of my way to: predict the next 10 seconds, use different styling, and different naming conventions, all to 'focus' more while following the project implementation.

For future project videos, here are some possible suggestions:
- Don't show solutions immediately for each part of the projects
- Make each project part a mini-assignment (of the whole)
- Give hints, some downloadable code stubs, and an objective
- Show the part's solution directly after

Thank you and I'd highly recommend this course to anybody!
results.content_html:

- Touches on the necessary basics of html, css, js, and python just enough (but not too much) to be able to do django, well planned.
- I like the repetition of various things across projects and exercises, really allows some concepts to sink in.

IMPROVEMENTS:
- During the django half, the project videos turn into a "watch me code" copy/paste series which dampens focus & slows down learning.
- I had to regularly go out of my way to: predict the next 10 seconds, use different styling, and different naming conventions, all to 'focus' more while following the project implementation.

For future project videos, here are some possible suggestions:

- Give hints, some downloadable code stubs, and an objective
- Show the part's solution directly after

Thank you and I'd highly recommend this course to anybody!

results.content:
Good course in general but a bit out of date - I had a lot of trouble when learning django as the version in the course is 1.11 and the current version is 3 already (the version in the notes is 2.0). Honestly it's quite unpleasant to jump between the version all the time. Same about Bootstrap but there it's not really important. I would appreciate some notes on the differences between the version. You watch the video in 1.1, then you open the notes  - it's 2.0 and the current version is 3. and you  have to compare it all yourself and find the difference. 
I also like the course on Python 3 much more from the same teacher - it's more convenient to learn. But in general the course is still good.

Starts off great with laying the basics of html, and css, but the Django part needs improvements, especially the clone projects in the end. There's barely any explanation, just typing along with the instructor. 
Maybe instead of recording the typing, use the time to explain the final solution instead.

results.content:
It was excellent up until midway where it felt it was getting progressively more rushed down the sections.

I came for Django, and sections pertaining to it was rather difficult to understand for someone without prior Django knowledge, like myself. 
I feel that the Django tutorials lack in delivering fundamental ideas and explanation of the codes were extremely generic — almost as though as he was just reading off the codes itself. Repetition of the codes were minimal which contributed to me having a hard time trying to understand the codes in the clone project videos. Overall, my personal opinion would be that this course is not for beginners and some reading up prior to the course would be a great benefit.

The tutorials and resources are not updated to the latest version as well.

results.content:
I had a basic knowledge on Python, which I taught myself through free online courses.
The challenges on html/css/js/python is really good for beginners to test what they have learned. This tutorial also helps you to understand the core basics of Python, and how to understand Django Frameworks.

However, the end of the tutorial seems very rushed. It's just copy/paste exercise. I didn't feel like I'm learning what Jose is doing, but more felt like copying what he is telling me to do.

There were many things that he didn't cover previously, which appears in the real-life example (e.g. Social Clone ), but he briefly explains and skips the details, which makes me to google what I just have missed. It makes me to think that it's better to study alone without paying if I were to google every obstacle i encounter.

results.content:
The first half of the course was extremely useful, well thought out and planned. Delivery method was concise and explanations for every action were given - there was an EDIP (Explain, demonstrate, imitate and practice) element to it.

The latter part of the course by comparison is out of date, and seems rushed - explanations aren't given for important concepts and no thought is given into why certain things are laid out or chosen - its more of a follow what im doing approach, which is quite poor for a technical course. 

Lucky the Django documentation is far more definitive.

Disappointing ending - only reason it isnt a 2 star or less is that the first half of the course balances out the latter half.

The first half of the course was extremely useful, well thought out and planned. Delivery method was concise and explanations for every action were given - there was an EDIP (Explain, demonstrate, imitate and practice) element to it.

The latter part of the course by comparison is out of date, and seems rushed - explanations aren't given for important concepts and no thought is given into why certain things are laid out or chosen - its more of a follow what im doing approach, which is quite poor for a technical course.

Lucky the Django documentation is far more definitive.

Disappointing ending - only reason it isnt a 2 star or less is that the first half of the course balances out the latter half.

results.content: First of all, I have a few years experience as a SW engineer. I do write code daily basis with Python. The first part of the course, which is about learning HTML / JS / CSS / Python is quite good. I did mostly just make a overview and didn't got in details. But it really looks good and well explained. The second part of the course, which teaches about Django framework is quite handy and one of the best courses I had. It is well explained. Each part starts from scratch but relays for the entire part on the first project which created on the first lecture of the current part, which is a great balance between exercise and not too much. This course is really handle to the viewer in enjoyably way. The instructor is great and make everything clear. Nothing is copy-paste, every line is explained and details. I highly recommend this course.

results.content:
O curso começa muito bem até cerca de 70/75% do curso, depois toma um ritmo acelerado difícil de acompanhar. Dá a impressão que o curso estava ficando mais longo do que o professor gostaria e ele começa a acelerar os conteúdos.
No projeto do Clone de um blog foi o que mais tive dificuldade, o professor ia de forma muito rápida desenvolvendo o projeto e em certas partes eu não fazia ideia do porquê ele estava escrevendo certa parte do código. Acho que seria melhor se ele fizesse o projeto em um formato de ir desenvolvendo e testando ao invés de desenvolver centenas de linhas e deixar tudo pra testar no final. 
E o Javascript do blog, não sei a partir de quando os textos começaram a ficar coloridos, que script foi usado, de onde surgiu aquilo.
No Arquivo Zip de Atualização para o Django 2.0, o javascript do blog aponta para  <script type="text/javascript" src="{% static 'js/blog.js' %}"></script>, arquivo este que não existe.
No fim o curso dá uma boa base e vale o investimento, entende-se que o professor incentiva que o aluno busque por si mesmo as soluções nas documentações e este formato pode ser o ideal para alguns, porém, a mim, deixou um gosto amargo de que paguei um curso e recebi um tutorial de como ler a documentação.
Em bom português, o curso é bom, tirando essa parte do "Se vira"

results.content: If your looking for course on Django2 and Python3.... this is intact NOT the course for you. I find myself spending a lot of time having to sift through old and new documentation to try and figure out how to make what the instructor is doing. Its truly frustrating and if I had realized this course was for obsolete content, I would have never purchased it. Also I think is irresponsible for Udemy to provide such out-dated content. I also found in a Python3 Bootcamp, that the tests we took were in an older version of python. So certain functions wouldn't work. Udemy needs to step their game up, and get with the times already!

results.content: This is the third course I've taken from Jose (I've previously finished his basic Python and Python for Data Science courses) and as usual it is a very clear and concise set of instruction. His ability to plainly and simply explain topics allows for even the least knowledgeable user to build a strong foundation to grow from. He takes the student down a very straight forward path and explains every keystroke he makes in his videos, and every reference in the resources thoroughly. If you've ever taken another course or tutorial where the instructor jumps from topic to topic, you know how frustrating it can be when something important was glossed over. Jose doesn't lead his students astray or wondering how they've gotten to where they are in a piece of instruction. Overall I'd say he is a top instructor overall for Udemy, especially in terms of data science and python related topics.

results.content:
This was an excellent course. 

The only problem is it's severely out of date and no attempts have been made to provide any supplemental materials to bridge the gap from Django 1 to Django 3. 

If I have any criticisms of the teaching style it's mostly that in the latter Django projects the teacher goes through long stretches without running code or debugging. Combine that with the fact that he's using a much older version of Django and it's difficult to follow along. 

On the plus side, if it were up to date, it's a very thorough course with detailed explanations and all the code is downloadable. 

If the teacher updates it to Django 3, I'd certainly take it again.
results.content_html:
This was an excellent course.

The only problem is it's severely out of date and no attempts have been made to provide any supplemental materials to bridge the gap from Django 1 to Django 3.

If I have any criticisms of the teaching style it's mostly that in the latter Django projects the teacher goes through long stretches without running code or debugging. Combine that with the fact that he's using a much older version of Django and it's difficult to follow along.

On the plus side, if it were up to date, it's a very thorough course with detailed explanations and all the code is downloadable.

If the teacher updates it to Django 3, I'd certainly take it again.

results.content:
A really good course for an absolute beginner like me.

I've been writing database-driven programmes in Filemaker pro for 13 years. It is a great environment and framework for really fast app development but it comes with some restrictions. I have almost no coding experience with other languages.

I did my research about what would be the fastest and easiest language to learn for the rapid development of solutions and apps and decided that Python and using the Django framework is the way forward for me. Next step then was discovering what software tools would be best and how to get a good solid foundation in the overall full stack web development using Python and Django in the shortest time frame to establish a good base and good working practices to build more knowledge onto.

Jose's course gets very high ratings on Python's website for learning Python. Halfway through I fully understand why.

I had minimal experience with websites, and having looked at javascript and php 18 months ago decided it was far to complex. This course makes perfect sense of everything, breaking the complex down into much more simple easy to digest chunks and I really like Jose's style and approach.  It all makes such good sense.  I've already purchased his Zero to hero course for Python to complete after I get through this full stack course.

Highly recommended.

results.content:
Great course for learning Django! I am currently going through this after going through the course from zero to hero in python. The python portions in this course have served to reinforce what I've previously learned. 
The only issue I have found in the course as of the time I am going through it, was that it hasn't been updated in a very long time. Luckily other people who have gone through the course have been very helpful, in that they have posted in the Q&A what has been changed and solutions to problems that are currently occuring. Would give a higher rating if this was more up to date. I understand that it is possible to simply go and look up the answers, but this is a paid course and the payment is made so that I can learn here not so that I have to do the research on my own...

results.content:
Great Course! I think the only thing lacking in this course is the visual aid during the explanation. The instructor does a good job of briefly explaining what each piece of code does, but for someone just learning django, without a visual aid it doesn't really make sense. 

It would be nice during the coding part that he pulls up the finished project and show on the finished site what we just coded instead of waiting to type out all the code and run the server.

results.content: This was a great course and very in-depth. The clone projects at the end are much encompassing. The amount of detail he teaches is great. The voice is very comfortable to listen to. He does go quite fast but I actually like that. It really forces you to learn to type fast and when that fails there's always the pause button. I highly recommend using the pause button. He used bootstrap3 for his styling in the projects. I tried to incorporate bootstrap4 in my projects when running parallel to him. That was a fun challenge. It's actually not that difficult. You just gotta read the docs and see how the styling and classes are supposed to be. I did really find one thing quite annoying, to be honest. From previous coding experience, which was mostly personal projects and a coding bootcamp, you always code a bit then see how your site is looking. Code some more, check out the site/app. Aka kinda test-driven development. Now, this is only functional testing/integration testing and not really unit testing but still. You should be trying to do some kind of test-driven development. This guy pretty much writes the code from 0 to 98 then starts up the server to see how things work and only then starts debugging. I'm not a pro but I'm not sure that's the best workflow. That's why deducted half a star. It would really be helpful if how in the beginning he showed the end product and during the actual process, you could see visually the functionality we're working on at the moment. I understand often that's not possible because lots of things are intertwined together. Most of the things you could do that though in my humble opinion. Again I'm just a student yet but... That one thing I think could be improved. Most people are very visual learners. Overall great course though. Would highly recommend it to others. Definitely code along and try to do certain things your own way. Like I used pipenv for my virtual environment. I liked that workflow much better. Also bootstrap4 as well as VSCode as my editor of choice. Doing certain things your own way really stimulated the brain juices and made the turn. ;)

Overall, I would highly recommend this course.

results.content:
Recomends MDN over W3Schools because MDN is more technical and accurate but the way he teaches is way sloppier than W3schools. Gives bad examples using elements in a way it is not meant to be used causing students think it is okay when there's no reason not to do the right way.

A lot of times he just types things but dont' explain what that code does. He is just copying it and gives the impression he actually don't know how the code works either.

results.content:
Jose has an amazing way to transfer knowledge and a sneaky way to make you understand fundumentals of debugging, a highly important task of a developer. Through excersises and code-along lectures he manage  to make one understand how the Django ecosystem works. 

What i personally miss from the course was a lecture about deploying in Heroku apart from pythonanywhere and/or digital ocean. 

Overall the course was fun and engaging enough, sometimes even more than i was expecting as i spend many hours sleepless to absorb as much as i can so i can implement on my own ideas.

Thanks a lot Jose my man!

results.content: Overall a good course to get familiar with Django capabilities. Although the video content had been recorded before Django 2.0 released, Jose attached updated version of notes which is very useful in case of experiencing any trouble with applications. The main reason why I didn't give it 5 stars is a lack of description of Django structure and its components, without which is tougher to understand some code lines without looking for information by yourself. Other than that, it's a great course and I definitely recommend it.

results.content:
The course is out of date and needs update. For example, PATHS() - new update in Django 3.6+ - is not reflected in the video.
I did like the author to explain the concept before diving into examples. For example, the author has not explained the workflow of how Django handles an incoming webquery - the importance of MVT architecture vs MVC architecture, and the entire process beakdown of a Django framework's handling of an incoming request.

I think the Author has done a good job of explaining HTML, JavaScript, Bootstram concepts in the early phase of the course...but the heart/core of the couese...Django needs to improve. Try showing the bigger picture of how Django works, before deep-diving into the coding and technical details.

results.content:
outdated course, confusing lectures. Initially had given this course a 2.5 stars and now reducing it to one.

Reasons:
1. Outdated course.
2. The instructor shows how to do things instead of explaining why things are happening.
3. The TA's equally confusing answers clearly shows someone with very superficial Django knowledge has been recruited to do the TA work. 
4. Its awfully explained when the course goes into advanced Django topics like CBVs. 3 min youtube videos were more explanatory than whatever the instructor keeps on doing over 15min+ videos.
5. The only plus side of this course is that it has an organised structure and so you will know what to study from Django after what. Basically after that you are on your own to find out elsewhere why the instructor did something in the video.

results.content: About 80% done. So far, course feels rushed. For an online course, it is sort of inevitable that the instructor will miss some small details. Unfortunately, this one seems to miss plenty. Some of the code are constantly re-used throughout the course yet I am still unable to understand what their functionalities are. It gives me an impression that those lines of code should simply be memorized and regurgitated on new files. Also, there are a lot of errors that force me to rewrite my notes back a couple lectures ago. While the instructor tries to warn us about this ahead of the error-ridden lecture, it remains helpless simply because that lecture continues teaching on as if the code is correct.

results.content:
Not recommended.
The course uses Django 1.11,  the current version is 3. From a relevance point of view, I simply cannot recommend this course. Apart from that, I have two major problems with this course: 
1. It makes us install Anaconda. I am almost at the end of the Django section of the course, and so far there has been absolutely no use for the entire 600 mb anaconda installation. The use of anaconda for making environments, could be easily done with using virtualenv, without installing all those additional libraries that are now hindering in my other development activities. This sets up a really bad precedent for other beginners, which will eventually face a lot of library issues when working or studying other things in Python. I personally have faced numerous dependency problems, simply because of anaconda. I have not used it once, even outside this course.
2. The course drags on the front end part of the full stack. HTML, bootstrap, CSS etc take a lot of time. And all of their sections have a mini project to go through the concepts learned. Extremely good, but these mini-projects, tests are absent from all the four major Django sections, the framework on which the entire course is based.  You go through 4 sections without practicing any django implementation. By the time Django started I quit the course and eventually moved on to other YouTube tutorials and experimenting on my own.
Apart from that several lectures have audio bugs with entire minutes without audio, or gibberish coming from sound. Why haven't they been fixed?
Absolutely not recommended. Maybe two years back this would actually be worth it, but as it stands right now, YouTube has much better tutorials on django.

results.content: The course has all the information needed to learn django, however i feel that he could explain django project sections a bit more well. Especially by breaking things and letting us know why it works and why different method doesn't work. As a beginner just showing a straight way of doing things, without breaking it makes it very difficult for the concepts to stick and building a strong foundation. For eg, why do we pass the 'request' method to the view functions, why pass 'pk' key to the view function. Could it be named something else? If this name is changed, where does it affect. These kind of information will be valuable especially for a beginner to understand from where these values are picked up from. Is it from the database? Or the urls?
results.content_html: The course has all the information needed to learn django, however i feel that he could explain django project sections a bit more well. Especially by breaking things and letting us know why it works and why different method doesn't work. As a beginner just showing a straight way of doing things, without breaking it makes it very difficult for the concepts to stick and building a strong foundation. For eg, why do we pass the 'request' method to the view functions, why pass 'pk' key to the view function. Could it be named something else? If this name is changed, where does it affect. These kind of information will be valuable especially for a beginner to understand from where these values are picked up from. Is it from the database? Or the urls?

Furthermore it doesnt show the basis of how to deal with databases (like mysql or postgresql) which you will need to use in real world...

results.content: This was a very enjoyable course! I actually learned more than I had expected.  Jose presents the material in a very effective manner; an overview, explaining the material while he is coding (and why he is doing it that way), and finally a review of what you should take away from the section. I would recommend this course to anyone ready to jump in and learn Python and Django (with more emphasis on Django).

Jose presents the material in a very effective manner; an overview, explaining the material while he is coding (and why he is doing it that way), and finally a review of what you should take away from the section. I would recommend this course to anyone ready to jump in and learn Python and Django (with more emphasis on Django).

results.content:
I am taking several courses from Mr. Portilla.  I really appreciate the quick response from him and his assistants and the structure of the courses.  It's a good starting point for everyone to explore different topics and maybe dive deeper as learning progresses.

The only suggestion that I would make is that it would be even better if we could have a basic project concept flow chart for each project so that students can conceptually understand how everything is linked together so that students can visualize exactly how each file or objects related to each other.  Anyway, it's a good practice to have some sort of concept chart before starting any project.

Sometimes, we may run into situations where the course' scripts or methods have been deprecated; however, that's just how technology works, it evolves 'constantly', so it does not bother me as much.  I believe it's part of the learning.

The course is a bit outdated by using an old version of Django and this can create some headaches if you don't downgrade. At least teaches you how to debug.

A lot of times you end up just copying what the instructor types on the screen, specially in the models.py, forms.py and views.py files. On these moments the classes feel very rushed and I don't know how the instructor came up with the solutions.

It can be a good introduction to Django but not enough to make you feel comfortable with it.

results.content: Really the only reason I'm not giving this course five stars is that it desperately needs to be updated to reflect changes between Django 1.0 and Django 3.0. I realize that most of the changes required are small(ish) and the Assistant is good about answering questions (plus, it does force you to go to the Django docs yourself). However, while working through the course it just got to be very old that a lot of the material either didn't work or was totally outdated. I found myself spending most of my time looking up the differences between the two versions in order to patch over the lesson. I would've rather liked to have spent that time immersed in the actual concepts and workflow of the projects. All in all, however, a great comprehensive course for Django.
results.content_html: Really the only reason I'm not giving this course five stars is that it desperately needs to be updated to reflect changes between Django 1.0 and Django 3.0. I realize that most of the changes required are small(ish) and the Assistant is good about answering questions (plus, it does force you to go to the Django docs yourself). However, while working through the course it just got to be very old that a lot of the material either didn't work or was totally outdated. I found myself spending most of my time looking up the differences between the two versions in order to patch over the lesson. I would've rather liked to have spent that time immersed in the actual concepts and workflow of the projects. All in all, however, a great comprehensive course for Django.

results.content:
This course was presented exceptionally well by Jose. The q&A section is well maintained by both Jose and other students. Additional course files were provided to suit updated versions of Django and course related software. 

The mentality Jose installs upon his students encourages investigation and exploration of the framework and further possibilities in development. Which in software development is critical.

Anyone looking to do this course will need to understand it was produced in an evolving framework. Prospective students are encouraged to learn the foundations that Jose presents in his lectures and be prepared to investigate the further changes in the later versions of the framework.

The key to success I found in this course is a never ending supply of coffee.  It might also be worthwhile setting an alarm clock to break yourself away from the screen every so often as it is quite addictive once you start getting into the later modules of the course. (Many sleepless sunrises).

Thank you Jose!!!
results.content_html:

results.content: I really wanted to love this course. The instructor was amazing until the point we reached Django. The Django sections of this course is outdated and he even though he recommends to use the version that he it using, it isn't possible. The version he uses in this course is deprecated meaning there's no way to use the source code or practice along with him. I have tried pretty much everything from downloading an old version of Jupiter Notebook and trying to download Django 1.1 but it's not possible. I messaged the instructor if he will update this course and he just told me to wait until the Django 3 course comes out and I asked if he would be at least go over the sections he promised to go over in the course such as Authentication and Stripe Integration and didn't receive a reply. This course should be taken offline completely since there's no way to use the version he is using in this course. If you want to learn Django especially the updated version I suggest Nick Walters Django 3 - Build Fullstack Websites course right here on Udemy. Sad to say that my experience with this course wasn't pleasant and wasted so much time going over the documentation to try and cope with the numerous errors I got. Avoid if possible.

results.content:
This is an incredible complete course, so much knowledge and as always, Jose is just an excellent professor.
The Front End and Python section are great, good exercises and well explained.
Nonetheless, I felt the Django Section a little hard to follow so I had to review some lectures to get a better understanding.
I would love to see more space in the backend and learn more about APIs and types of architecture, but as a very first approach to the Django world, I would not be more satisfied. Thank you, Jose!!

results.content: This is not my first course with this instructor,  but this one, in my opinion, is unacceptable - you send 3/4 of the course talking about conceptual framework that could be covered in 3 lectures  (and never gets used in the real world) vs 20+ hours ... Once you finally get to Django part of lectures, you once again go over basic concepts that you can through out of the window, because once again you this is not how things are done in real projects. And when you get to Clone projects where you should be solidifying your knowledge and practicing acquired skills you are told to reference the documentation over and over again without much explanation of why / how things work ... My recommendation to the instructor  is to spend more time on the real world examples and explanations in. of what exact fields Model.User has vs  "...there is a great page about it in the documentation..."

results.content:
So far, so good. I'm a little disappointed that A. we 're using anaconda rather than a vanilla install of python with virtualenv and B. that the course is so outdated.   The latest version of Django is now 3.0.3 and python 3.8.1.  I should have read the description of the course more thoroughly.  Anyway, besides that, the explanations are clear and are moving on at a good pace.

I've now finished the course.  I'm pretty pleased with the course.  Jose does a great job at explaining pretty much everything.  As I said previously, I'd  quite like to do the same course but with the latest Django version.  However, the notes provided do have updated files if you need to copy.  My approach was to write the code along with Jose so there were things that didn't add up.  I didn't want to just copy and paste.  It's only because of that, that I didn't give the course 5 stars.
results.content_html:

I've now finished the course. I'm pretty pleased with the course. Jose does a great job at explaining pretty much everything. My approach was to write the code along with Jose so there were things that didn't add up. I didn't want to just copy and paste. It's only because of that, that I didn't give the course 5 stars.

results.content:
Amazing Course with amazing knowledge shared by Jose. 

Pros-
-Beginer Friendly
-Related Topics like HTML, CSS, JS, Jquerry
-Amazing Community Support

Cons
- NO Latest version support- Upgrading from older to newer versions 
- Pro Level concepts like- User Authentication and Authorisation , Django Channels 

My Opinion:
This course is awesome when you want to begin with Web developement, but as you grow mature with the topics you will have to venture on your own to try and solve the problems you face, and yes there is a solution to every probelm you face. So its a great course to give head start in the world of Web Development.

I'm not even 10% done and I have taken many other courses on the basics of HTML and CSS but, unlike those, the instructor here explains everything very fast and clear. I love the fact that he gives exercises for you to practice what you have learned.
Edit: As I'm at about 60% done with this course I have to take my review down from 5 stars to 4.5 because although I have learned quite a lot some of the projects weren't really explained much and he just ran through the code. In other words, some things are not as beginner-friendly yet the instructor manages to deliver all the information and resources required to further your understanding.

results.content:
The course is perfect.  I've done a couple of other courses like this, one on .NetCore and one for Rails, and none are as succinct and thorough as this course.  The html, css and bootstrap sections (which I didn't need to go through, and if you have done any html or css you won't need to either) are the exact amount you need to know to get yourself moving towards backend development.  Really great teaching structure, information is clear and follows a really easy to follow flow.  

Great course, I'm not surprised it's the most recommended Django course on the interwebs.

*Everything was going great until we got to Part 2 of Python, then I had to go to other sources to learn some concepts, and I understood them perfectly elsewhere to finish out Python 2 with a solid understanding. Django? The pace suddenly became insane and everything because less cohesive. Again, I had to go to other sources for the basics. Not sure why there's such a big difference in how the earlier part of the course was taught vs. the part most of us actually came for, Python and Django.

results.content:
I have taken Jose's Python course, which led me to taking this course. 

The structure of the course is great. Jose starts by teaching you all the concepts you need in detail (from Html, Css, Bootstrap, Javascript, jQuery, the DOM and Python, and then the individual concepts you need to understand in Django.) After that the two clone projects help you to solidify your knowledge. 

I am confident of this: after I complete this course (I am almost finished) I will be able to build all the the applications I have in mind for my education business. 

The $20 I paid for Jose's Python Course and the Django Bootcamp, and the 100 hours or so I spent learning from Jose, are one of the best investments I have made into my education in my life. 

Next I plan to take your Data Science class. You are a great teacher.  

Thanks Jose.

results.content:
This course is decent at best. I feel like the early sections of the course are done rather well though, apart from the JavaScript and jQuery sections which  seemed a bit rushed.

My biggest gripe with this course is the django section, the clone-projects in particular. You might as well not do them because they are literally just code-alongs with new concepts getting brought up having little to no explanations. The instructor even encourages the learners to not bother writing some long code and just copy-paste from the notes. That is absolutely baffling, does he expect us to learn in this manner?

The social project in particular was the most poorly explained, especially since it uses multiple applications, a concept we only get to cover only in this project . Would have been way better to explain the entire structure of the project and how the multiple apps will communicate with each other, rather than building out the app outright without understanding the flow.

results.content:
Generally I've enjoyed this instructor's classes but this course is pretty outdated. After taking it, while I knew how to start a social media forum or a blog, but I didn't really know how to do anything else, despite this class being 30+ hours.

There is a ton of material covered, but honestly there's too much focus on the unimportant parts (for example the css section is not very useful, and the js section is essentially useless since the instructor doesn't even use it in the final 2 projects).

Another bad thing is that the instructor starts off using one directory structure in the first final project (the company blog) while in the second directory structure, he uses a completely different directory structure. This is extremely confusing to people like me who aren't 100% sure how to go about creating a new site. Jose, if you're reading this - CHOOSE ONE template directory structure and stick to it. 

However, all of the above is not a big deal, probably still warrants a 4.5 rating.

The worst part about this class is that it is extremely outdated, even though it's only been 1.5 years.

What's outdated?
1) Django 1 is taught in the class, now Django 2 resolved a LOT of issues that were in Django 1. For example, you no longer need to use regular expressions in the URLs.py file. That saves a crap ton of time debugging as most of us python beginners do NOT understand regular expressions at all.

2) A lot of modules have had their names changed. Not the biggest deal, but it will get you stuck and add to your debug time.

3) Bootstrap 3 is taught in the class, while Bootstrap 4 is now widely available. Not as huge of a difference as above, but still, you're basically stuck either learning an outdated css style or having to lookup your own Bootstrap 4 tags.

Honestly, this entire class can be taught in 10 hours if the material is presented in a better way, and also if the information wasn't so outdated. There are way better tutorials online that cover bootstrap 4 and django 2.1.

If you completely don't know anything about python I'd still recommend this class, but if you already know a little python and just want to make your own website using Django asap, don't take this class because there are far better, more updated (and FREE) options out on Youtube.

Overall, I still enjoy this instructor's courses a lot, but the outdated nature of this course is a full -2 stars.

results.content:
It has been a great course; though I would say that the social clone project has a better flow than the blog- i.e we did something, that was explained, we did another thing, that was explained and so-on.  The blog was frustrating at times, because it was hard to remember every step we took and know how it led to a given result.

The only things I would suggest to add would be some dedicated videos that explain things like models and how they relate to SQL, url patterns and how Django is resolving them in different situations and how that lands you at a given template, and some instruction upfront telling you that you need to install a particular version of Django and how to do so with pip.

Does not explain the things why some things are done and how it has gotten to the exact solution. Course lacks explaining of "programmer mindset" problem solving thought process and so on.

Program language is if statement here, variable there, use for loop here, but that is not programming... Everyone can learn these beginner stuff in a day or two. Programming is more about mindset and logical thinking. Which is developed over time. course should have been more focused on how to break down the problem and why you write what you write. not just code along or watch along. It gets repetitive and non engaging.
