results.content: This is the 5th Jose Portilla course I took in the past 6 months. He's one of my top-3 instructors here and his courses are really well done. This is the first one that I didn't give 5-star. I have no regrets to take the course but I feel the Django topics a little bit confusing. It's too much in code along and little theory in how things fit with each other. As my improvement suggestions, I would recommend more sections explaining template taggings, URLs/views links, HTML blocks, and how the HTML link with the views. I'm still a little bit confused. We had Jquery and JavaScript sections, but I didn't see too much use applied to the core of the course (Django).
results.content_html: This is the 5th Jose Portilla course I took in the past 6 months. He's one of my top-3 instructors here and his courses are really well done. This is the first one that I didn't give 5-star. I have no regrets to take the course but I feel the Django topics a little bit confusing. It's too much in code along and little theory in how things fit with each other. As my improvement suggestions, I would recommend more sections explaining template taggings, URLs/views links, HTML blocks, and how the HTML link with the views. I'm still a little bit confused. We had Jquery and JavaScript sections, but I didn't see too much use applied to the core of the course (Django).

results.content:
As a brand new python (programmer) I use the term loosely,
I was able to finish both django projects and get them to function.  I will say at the point of the second one I personally felt I was "going through the motions on much of the content".  There was a TON of information and that is not a bad thing the value of this course is superb.  But at the completion I wish I had not rushed into the deep end of the pool, I completely intend to take Jose's Zero to Hero course, and come back and rebuild the blog project and the social clone project several times to see how many lights turn on.  Jose really knows his stuff, my reception there of is the main variable of frustration from my point of view.

My only "complaint" may not even be "fair" however, I am going to state it anyway.  When reading the Q&A a lot of times the response is did you use your code or my code?  That is a fair question, but my hope in taking this course is I would be able to start projects freelancing or whatever, so if I was doing that I would not have your code to copy paste into said project, and the expectation as lofty as it may be from my little corner of the world is I would understand how to clean up "my code".  I think with more work on my part that is a very reasonable expectation, my point is only that providing that answer frustrates the student who is hoping to have more understanding so I can use "my code".  The debug phase of each project was well done and the parts that didn't exactly match where Jose had minor errors to fix I was able to fumble my way through or google the error message and find a solution pretty quickly, I do consider those to be reasonable expectations of the student, and I feel that because of Jose's course I was able to fix all errors and get both projects running.  

Over all this is an excellent course, and I think if you are better at learning than me, or already have a very good grasp of 1)python for starters, 2)html, css, java, which are not very heavy in the end of the course you will be writing django projects on your own with the materials provided here.  So for my part I am going to do more in depth study of those areas, and continue to refer to this course until I am very proficient in the materials and concepts provided here.

Thank you Jose,

But at the completion I wish I had not rushed into the deep end of the pool, I completely intend to take Jose's Zero to Hero course, and come back and rebuild the blog project and the social clone project several times to see how many lights turn on. Jose really knows his stuff, my reception there of is the main variable of frustration from my point of view.

That is a fair question, but my hope in taking this course is I would be able to start projects freelancing or whatever, so if I was doing that I would not have your code to copy paste into said project, and the expectation as lofty as it may be from my little corner of the world is I would understand how to clean up "my code". I think with more work on my part that is a very reasonable expectation, my point is only that providing that answer frustrates the student who is hoping to have more understanding so I can use "my code". The debug phase of each project was well done and the parts that didn't exactly match where Jose had minor errors to fix I was able to fumble my way through or google the error message and find a solution pretty quickly, I do consider those to be reasonable expectations of the student, and I feel that because of Jose's course I was able to fix all errors and get both projects running.

Over all this is an excellent course, and I think if you are better at learning than me, or already have a very good grasp of 1)python for starters, 2)html, css, java, which are not very heavy in the end of the course you will be writing django projects on your own with the materials provided here. So for my part I am going to do more in depth study of those areas, and continue to refer to this course until I am very proficient in the materials and concepts provided here.

Thank you Jose,

results.content:
PROS:
- The amount this course covers is astonishing
- This is Jose's course. He's the best. 

CONS:
- Due to high frequency of Django's updates, the video will show different syntax and different folder structures for Django. The video was made using Django 1 while current Django is 3. If I remember it correctly Django 4 will come out next year. 
- Django's section is taught very fast
- There aren no lectures about SQLite. We just slightly use them in the background so if you want to learn more about SQL, I recommend Jose's other course dedicated for it. 

WORKAROUND:
- When you reach to the section for Django, I recommend NOT to code along since the syntax and codes are different between Django 1 and 3 . Instead I recommend using the material which has been updated to Django 3 and just take notes using them. Some directories are different but you can pretty much ignore that. 
- Use the Q&A whenever you have questions if Django 1 & 3 don't match up. Most of them should be answered in the Q&A thanks to Jose and the users. Just paste that line of code you want to find more about. 
- Similar thing can happen to the lectures for Bootstrap. It's really up to you if you want to use the latest version or not since the lectures are not that long. 

PERSONAL ADVICE:
- To me section of Django was very difficult. There were variables with the same name which comes from many different sources (e.g. post, posts, post-list, etc). If you are taking notes, I highly recommend color-coding them on your notes to keep track where they are coming from. For the last clone project I had to use multiple highlight colors as well as text colors  
- Around the end of the course I came across to two packages which I highly recommend for you to install on ATOM. One is "django-templates" which helps you auto-complete and color the syntax for Django. The other is "hyperclick". I believe this has to be used with "django-templates" and it will allow you to COMMAND-CLICK (mac) on the variables and it will take you back to the source where it was originally defined. I haven't tested on Django's syntax but I wish I had this early on. 
- Jose may or may not update the video or start a new course Django 3.1 and above in the future. 


Best of luck!

@Jose, 
Thank you so much for bringing out this course into the world. 
I look forward if you ever decide to create a follow up course or a new course using Django 3.1 or 4.

results.content:
This course is very through, covering a lot of detail.  it's content is excellent.   I am disappointed as to how the course is delivered.  As a developer, and talking with other developers, we do not create 5-6 forms at a time, and in this case, url and model files.  We create a form, whether it be create, delete,etc, and debug it at the time we create it.    In this course, we debug 4-5 forms and processes at a time.  Now, this may be done to speed the course along.

The other issue I have is that functions/procs are used, with a description of what, but often, the why is omitted.  For example, 'select_related' is used often, then all of a sudden 'prefetch_related' is used with no explanation as to why.

There is a lot of references to the django documentation.  I has to spend a lot of time reading through the documentation.  Being that I don't have 8 hours per day to study the course, I'm on my fourth month, trying to remember what was covered earlier in the course.

Lastly, better descriptions could  be provided in the course content/lists.  If these videos are to be used as a reference, there is no way other than going through an entire lecture when you are looking for one specific topic.  With listings such as 'Social Clone Part One', 'Blog Clone Project Part Four', etc, it's very time consuming to find a topic.
results.content_html:

results.content:
This course begins excellent and stays excellent right up to the clone projects.

Once we reach the clone projects, we are presented with lecture after lecture where we're following along and writing code. We debug at the end of these lectures, rather than doing so along the way.

I don't find this a very productive way of a) developing or b) learning a subject. By the time we're ready to test/debug all the features of our application, we're not necessarily familiar enough with what we've done to correct problems quickly. In many cases, it is even difficult to understand how the code we've written actually behaves. We've written so much code by the end of these sections it's very painful to backtrack. The lecturer even suggests just copying/pasting code from the notes if there's some kind of error. What do we ever learn from that? Plus, if we're not testing out features as we go, how do we even remember what features there are to test?

I think it would have been far more valuable to incrementally clone a single project rather than write 2 from start to finish and try to wrangle sense of them after we've vomited out all of the code.

I can't imagine trying to do any development work this way. It really flies in the face of incremental testing/development, and detracted from the quality of the course.

Still, it's a very good course overall.
